div.p: Greenes Tu quoque, OR, The Cittie Gallant. As it hath beene diuers times acted by the Queenes Maiesties Seruants, Written by IO. COOKE Gent.
Printed at London for Iohn Trundle. 1614.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: TO gratulate the loue and memory of my worthy friend the Author, and my entirely beloued Fellow, the Actor, I could not chuse being in the way iust when this Play was to be published in Priut, but to prefixe some token of my affection to either in the frontispire of the Booke. For the Gentleman that wrote it, his Poem it selfe can better speake his praise, then any Oratory from me. Nor can I tell whether this worke was diuulged with his consent or no: but howsoeuer, since it hath past the Test of the stage with so generall an applause, pitty it were but it should likewise haue the honour of the Presse. As for Maister Greene, all that I will speake of him (and that without flattery) is this (if I were worthy to censure) there was not an Actor of his nature in his time of better ability in performance of what he vndertooke; more applaudent by the Audience, of greater grace at the Court, or of more general loue in the Citty, and so with this briefe character of his memory, I commit him to his rest.

div.head: Vpon the death of Thomas Greene.

lg.l: How fast bleake Autumne changeth Floraes dye,
What yesterday was (Greene) now's seare & dry.

div.head: Greenes Tu Quoque.
div.stage: A Mercers Shop discouered, Gartred working in it, Spendall walking by the Shop: M Ballance walking ouer the Stage: after him Longfield and Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: WHat lacke you sir? faire stuffes, or veluets?

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.p: Good morrow Franke.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good morrow master Ballance.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Saue you master Long-field.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And you sir, what businesse drawes you toward this end o'th towne?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Faith no great serious affaires, onely a stirring humour to walke, and partly to see the beauties of the Citie; but it may be you can instruct me: pray whose shop's this?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why tis Will Rashes fathers, a man that you are well acquainted with. Enter a wench with a basket of linnen

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: As with your selfe; and is that his sister?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Marry is it sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray let vs walke, I would beholde her better.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Buy some quaifes, handkerchers, or very good bonelace Mistris.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Will you buy any handkerchers, sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, haue you any fine ones?

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.p: Ile shew you choice, please you looke sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: How now! what newes?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Mistris Tickleman has sent you a Letter, and expects your company at night, and intreats you to send her an angell, whether you can come, or whether you can not. He reades.

sp.speaker: Spend.

body.p: Sweet rascall! if your loue be as earnest as your protestation, you will meete me this night at Supper, you know the randeuows, there will be good company, a noise of choice Fidlers, a fine boy with an excellent voice, very good songs and bawdy; and which is more, I doe purpose my selfe to be exceeding merry: but if you come not, I shall powt my selfe sicke, and not eate one bit tonight.

closer.signed: Your continuall close friend, Nan Tickle-man.

sp.p: I pray send me an angell by this bearer, whether ye can come, or whether ye cannot. What's the price of these two?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Halfe a crowne in truth, sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Hold thee, there's an angell, and commend me to my delight, tell her I will not faile her, though I loose my freedome by't. Exit wench.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: I thanke you sir; buy any fine handkerchers?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You are taken sir extreamely, what's the obiect?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Shee's wonderous faire.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Nay, and your thoughts bee on wenching Ile leaue you.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: You shall not be so vnfriendly, pray assist mee; Wee'l to the shop and cheapen stuffes or sattins.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What lacke you Gentlemen? fine stuffes, veluets, or sattins? pray come neare.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let me see a good sattin.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You shall sir, what colour?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith I am indifferent, what colour most affects you Lady?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Without offence (faire creature) I demaund it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Sir, I beleeue it, but I neuer did
Tie my affection vnto any colour.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But my affection (fairest) is fast tied
Vnto the crimson colour of your cheeke.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You rellish too much Courtier, sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What's the price of this?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Fifteene indeede sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You set a high rate on't, it had neede be good.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Good! if you find a better i'th towne, Ile giue you mine for nothing: if you were my owne brother, I'de put it into your hands, looke vpon't, t'is close wrought, and has an excellent glasse.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I, I see't.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Pray sir come into the next roome; I'le shew you that of a lower price shall (perhappes) better please you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This fellow has an excellent tongue, sure hee was brought vp in the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Will you come in sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No, t'is no matter, for I meane to buy none.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Pre thee walke in, what you bargaine for, Ile discharge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Say so; fall to your worke, Ile be your chapman.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why doe you say I flatter? Exeunt Spend. Long.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Why? you doe;
And so doe all men when they women wooe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Who lookes on heauen, and not admires the worke?
Who viewes a well cut Diamond, does not praise
The beauty of the Stone? if these deserue
The name of Excellent, I lacke a word
For thee which meritst more,
More then the tongue of man can attribute.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: This is pretty Poetry, good fiction this: Sir, I must leaue you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Leaue with me first some comfort.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What would you craue?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: That which I feare you will not let me haue.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You doe not know my bounty; Say what t'is.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No more (faire creature) then a modest kisse.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: If I should giue you one, would you refraine, on that condition, ne'r to begge againe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I dare not grant to that.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Then't seemes you haue,
Though you get nothing, a delight to craue,
One will not hurt my lippe, which you may take,
Not for your loue, but for your absence sake. So farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O fare thee well (faire regent of my soule)
Neuer let ill sit neere thee, vnlesse it come
To purge it selfe; be as thou euer seemst,
An Angell of thy Sex, borne to make happy
The man that shall possesse thee for his Bride.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Wil you haue it for thirteene shillings and six pence? Ile fall to as lowe a price as I can, because Ile buy your custome.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now man! what! intranced?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good sir, ha you done?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes faith, I thinke as much as you, and t'is iust nothing: where's the wench?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Shee's heere sir, heere.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Vds pitty! vnbutton man, thou'lt stifle her else.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay good sir, will you goe?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: With all my heart, I stay but for you.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Doe you heare sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What say?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Will you take it for thirteene?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Not a penny more then I bid. Ex. Ger. & Long.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why then say you might haue had a good bargaine; Where's this boy to make vp the wares? heere's some tenne peeces opened, and all to no purpose. Enter Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Franke! shut vp shop, shut vp shop.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Shut vp shop, boy, why?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
My Master is come from the Court knighted, and bid
vs, for he sayes he will haue the first yeare of the reigne of his Knighthood kept holiday; here he comes. Enter sir Lionell.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: God giue your worship ioy, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Lion.
sp.p: O Francke! I haue the worship now in the right kinde, the sword of Knighthood sticks stil vpon my shoulders, and I feele the blow in my purse, it has cut two leather bagges asunder; but all's one, honour must be purchac'd: I will giue ouer my Citty coate, and betake my selfe to the Court iacket; as for trade, I will deale in't no longer, I will seate thee in my shop, and it shall be thy care to aske men what they lacke, my stocke shall be summed vp, and I will call thee to an account for it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: My seruice sir, neuer deseru'd so much,
Nor could I euer hope so large a bounty
Could spring out of your loue.

sp.speaker: Sir Lion.
sp.l: That's all one,
I do loue to do things beyond mens hopes,
To morrow I remooue into the Strand,
There for this quarter dwell, the next at Fulham:
He that hath choice, may shift, the whilst shalt thou
Be maister of this house, and rent it free.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Lion.
sp.p: To day Ile go dine with my Lord Maior: to morrow with the Sherifes, and next day with the Aldermen, I will spread the Ensigne of my knighthood ouer the face of the Citty, which shall strike as great a terrour to my enemies, as euer Tamberlaine to the Turkes.

lg.l: Come Franke, come in with me, and see the meate,
Vpon the which my knighthood first shall eate. Ex: omnes.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p:
There is a diuell has haunted me these three yeares, in likenesse of an Vsurer, a fellow that in all his life neuer eat three groat loaues out of his owne purse, nor neuer warmed him but at other mens fires, neuer saw a ioynt of mutton in his owne house these foure and twenty yeares, but alwayes cosoned the poore prisoners, for he alwayes bought his victualls
out of the almes-basket, and yet this rogue now feedes vpon capons which my tenants sent him out of the Countrey; he is Landlord forsooth ouer all my possessions: well, I am spent, and this rogue has consumed me; I dare not walke abroade to see my friends, for feare the Serieants should take acquaintance of me: my refuge is Ireland, or Virginia; necessitie cries out, and I will presently to Westchester. Enter Bubble .How now! Bubble hast thou pack'd vp all thy things? our parting time is come: nay pre thee doe not weepe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Affection sir will burst out.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Thou hast beene a faithfull seruant to me, go to thy vncle, hee'l giue thee entertainement, tell him vpon the stonie rocke of his mercilesse hart my fortunes suffer shipwracke.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will tell him he is an vsuring rascall, and one that would do the Common-wealth good, if he were hanged.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Which thou hast cause to wish for, thou arte his heire, my affectionate Bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: But Master, wherefore should we be parted?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Because my fortunes are desperate, thine are hopefull.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why but whither doe you meane to goe Maister?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why to Sea.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: To sea! Lord blesse vs, me thinks I heare of a tempest already, but what will you doe at Sea?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why as other Gallants doe that are spent, turne pyrate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: O Maister! haue the grace of Wapping before your eyes, remember a high tide, giue not your friends cause to wet their handkerchers: nay Maister, Ile tell you a better course then so, you and I will goe and robbe mine vncle; if we scape, wee'le dominiere together, if we be taken, wee'le be hanged together at Tyburne, that's the warmer gallowes of the two.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: By your leaue sir, whereabouts dwels one M. Bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Doe you heare, my friend, doe you know M. Bubble if you doe see him?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: No in truth doe I not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What is your businesse with Maister Bubble?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Marry sir, I come with welcome newes to him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tell it, my friend, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: May I be assured sir, that your name is master Bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I tell thee, honest friend, my name is master Bubble, Master Bartholomew Bubble.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Why then sir, you are heire to a million, for your vncle the rich vsurer is dead.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray thee honest friend, goe to the next Haberdashers, and bid him send me a new melancholy hat, and take thou that for thy labour.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: I will sir. Exit.

div.stage: Enter another Messenger hastily, and knockes.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Vmh, vmh, vmh.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I would the newes were true; see how my little Bubble is blowne vp with't!

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Doe you heare, my friend, for what doe you knocke there?

sp.speaker: 2. Mes.
sp.p: Marry sir, I would speake with the worshipfull Master Bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: The worshipfull! and what would you doe with the worshipfull Master Bubble? I am the man.

sp.speaker: 2. Mes.
sp.p: I cry your worship mercy then, Master Thong the Belt-maker sent me to your worship, to giue you notice, that your vncle is dead, and that you are his onely heire. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Thy newes is good, and I haue look'd for't long,
Thankes vnto thee, my friend, and goodman Thong.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Certainely, this newes is true: for see another, by this light his Scriuener! now M. Blancke, whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Maister Staines, God saue you, where is your man?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why looke you sir, do you not see him?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: God saue the right worshipfull master Bubble; I bring you heauy newes with a light heart.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I am your worships poore Scriuener.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He is an honest man it seems, for he has both his eares.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
I am one that your worships vncle committed some
trust in for the putting out of his mony, and I hope I shall haue the putting out of yours.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: The putting out of mine! would you haue the putting out of money?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yea sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No sir, I am olde enough to put out my owne mony.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I haue writings of your worships.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: As thou lou'st thy profite, hold thy tongue, thou and I will conferre.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Do you heare, my friend, can you tell me when, and how my vncle died?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes sir, he died this morning, and hee was kill'd by a Butcher?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How! by a Butcher?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, for going this morning into the Market, to cheapen meate, hee fell downe starke dead, because a Butcher ask'd him foure shillings for a shoulder of Mutton.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: How stark dead! & could not aqua vitae fetch him again?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: No sir, nor Rosa solis neither, and yet there was triall made of both.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: I shall loue aqua vitae & rosa solis the better while I liue.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Will it please your worship to accept of my poore seruice, you know my case is desperate, I beseech you that I may feed vpon your bread, tho it be of the brownest, and drinke of your drinke tho it be of the smallest, for I am humble in body, and deiected in minde, and will do your worship as good seruice for forty shillings a yeare, as another shall for 3. pounds.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will not stand with you for such a matter, because you haue beene my master, but otherwise, I will entertaine no man without some Knights or Ladies Letter for their behauiour, Geruase I take it is your christen name.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Yes if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Well Geruase, be a good seruant, and you shall finde me a dutifull master: and because you haue beene a Gentleman, I will entertaine you for my Tutor in behauiour; Conduct me to my pallace. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter Geraldine as in his study reading.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: As little children loue to play with fire,
And will not leaue till they themselues doe burne,
So did I fondly dally with Desire:
Vntill Loues flames grew hote, I could not turne,
Nor well auoyde; but sigh and sob, and mourne
As children doe, when as they feele the paine,
Till tender mother kisse them whole againe.
Fie, what vnsauery stuffe is this? but shee,
Whose mature iudgement can distinguish things,
Will thus conceit; tales that are harshest told,
Haue smoothest meanings, and to speake are bold:
It is the first-borne Sonet of my braine,
We suck'd a white leafe from my blacke-lipp'd penne
So sad employment, Enter Will Rash and Long field.
Yet the dry paper drinkes it vp as deep,
As if it flowed from Petrarkes cunning Quill.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How now! what haue we heere, a Sonet and a Satire coupled together like my Ladies Dogge and her Munkie; As little children &c.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pre thee away, by the deepest oath that can be sworne, thou shalt not reade it, by our friendship I coniure thee, pre thee let goe.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Now in the name of Cupid, what want'st thou, a pigeon, a doue, a mate, a turtle, dost loue fowle, ha?
O no, shee's fairer thrice then is the Queene,
Whom beauteous Venus called is by name, pre thee let mee know what she is thou louest, that I may shunae her, if I should chance to meete her.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why Ile tell you sir what she is, if you do not know.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: No not I, I protest.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why t'is your sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How! my sister?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, your eldest sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Now God blesse the man, he had better chuse a wench that has been borne and bred in an alley, her tongue is a perpetuall motion, Thought is not so swift as it is; and for pride, the woman that had her Ruffe poak'd by the diuell, is but a Puritan to her, thou could'st neuer haue fastned thy affection on a worse subiect, shee'l flowt faster then a court-waiting woman
in progresse, any man that comes in the way of honesty does she set her marke vpon, that is, a villainous leaft; for she is a kinde of Poetesse, and will make Ballads vpon the calues of your legges: I pre thee let her alone, shee'l neuer make a good wife for any man vnlesse it be a Leather dresser; for perhaps he, in time, may turne her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thou hast a Priuiledge to vtter this,
But by my life my owne bloud could not scape
A chasticement for thus prophaning her,
Whose vertues sits aboue mens calumnies,
Had mine owne brother spoke thus liberally,
My fury should haue taught him better manners.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No more words as you feare a challenge.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I may tell thee in thine eare, I am glad to heare what I do; I pray God send her no worse husband, nor he no worse wife: do you heare loue, will you take your Cloak and Rapier, and walke abroad into some wholesome aire? I do much feare thy infection, good councell I see will do no good on thee, but pursue the end, and to thy thoughts, Ile proue a faithfull friend.

div.stage: Enter Spendall, Nan Tickleman, Sweat man, Pursenet, and a Drawer.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Here's a spacious roome to walke in, sirra set downe the candle, and fetch vs vp a quart of Ipocras, and so wee'l part.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: Nay faith Sonne, wee'l haue a pottle, let's ne'r be couetous in our yong dayes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A pottle sirra, doe you heare?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Yes sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: How now Wench! how dost?

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p: Faith I am somewhat sicke, yet I should be well enough if I had a new gowne.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why heere's my hand, within these three dayes thou shalt haue one.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: And will you (sonne) remember me for a new fore-part, by my troth, my old one is worne so bare, I am asham'd any body should see't.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why, did I euer faile of my promise?

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: No in sinceritie didst thou not. Enter Drawer.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Heere's a cup of rich Ipocras.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Here sister, mother, and master Pursnet; nay good sir, be not so deiected, for by this wine, to morrow I will send you stuffe for a new suite, and as much as shall line you a cloake cleane through.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I thanke you, and shall study to deserue.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Heere boy, fill, and hang that eurmogin that's good for no body but himselfe.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Heroickly spoken by this Candle, t'is pity thou wert not made a Lord.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A Lord! by this Light I doe not thinke but to bee Lord Maior of London before I die, and haue three Pageants carried before me, besides a Shippe and an Vnicorne; prentices may pray for that time, for whensoeuer it happens, I will make another Shrouetuesday for them. Enter Drawer.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Yong master Rash has sent you a quart of Maligoe.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: M: Rash! zownds how does he know I am here?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Nay, I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Know not! it comes through you and your rascally glib-tongu'd companions, t'is my Masters sonne, a fine gentleman he is, & a boon companion, I must go soe him. Exit Spend.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: Boy, fill vs a cup of your maligo, wee'l drinke to M. Spendall in his absence, there's not a finer spirit of a Cittizen within the walles, here master Pursnet you shall pledge him.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Ile not refuse it were it puddle: by Stix he is a bountifull Gentleman, and I shall report him so: heere M Tickleman, shall I charge you?

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p: Doe your worst Sergeant, Ile pledge my yoong Spendall a whole sea, as they say, fa la la la la, would the Musicke were heere againe, I doe beginne to be wanton, Ipocras sirra, and a drie bisket; here bawd, a carowse.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: Bawd! I faith you beginne to grow light ith head, I pray, no more such words, for if you doe, I shall grow into distempers.

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p:
Distempers! hang your distempers, be angry with
me and thou dar'st, I pray, who feedes you, but I? who keepes the feather-beddes from the Brokers, but I? tis not your sawsege face, thicke clowted creame rampallion at home, that snuffles in the nose like a decayed Bagge-pipe.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Nay, sweete Mistris Tickle-man, be concordant, reuerence Antiquitie.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Saue you, sweete creatures of beauty, saue you: How now olde Belzebub, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: Belzebub! Belzebub in thy face.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Nay, good words Mistris Swearman, hee's a young Gallant, you must not weigh what he sayes.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I would my lamentable complayning Louer had beene heere, heere had beene a Supersede as for his melancholy, and yfaith Francke I am glad my father has turn'd ouer his shop to thee, I hope I, or any friend of mine, shall haue so much credite with thee, as to stand in thy bookes for a suite of Sattin.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: For a whole peece, if you please, any friend of yours shall command me to the last remnant.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why God a mercy Francke, what, shall's to dice?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Dice or drincke, heere's forty crownes, as long as that will last, any thing.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why there spoke a gingling Boy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A pox of money, t'is but rubbish, and he that hoord's it vp, it but a Scauenger: if there be cardes ith house, let's goe to Primero.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Primero! why I thought thou hadst not been so much gamster as to play at it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Gamster (to say truth) I am none, but what is it I will not be in good company? I will fit my selfe to all humors, I will game with a Gamster, drinke with a drunkard, be ciuill with a cittizen, fight with a swaggerer, and drabbe with a whoore-master.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: An excellent humour yfaith.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Zownds what haue we heere?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A land Porpoise, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: This is no angry, nor no roaring boy, but a blustering boy; now Eolus defend vs, what puffes are these?

sp.speaker: Swag.
sp.p: I doe smell a whoore.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: O Gentlemen, giue him good words, hee's one of the roaring boyes.

sp.speaker: Swag.
sp.p: Rogue.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Heere sir.

sp.speaker: Swag.
sp.p: Take my cloake, I must vnbuckle, my pickled oysters worke; puffe, puffe.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Puffe, puffe.

sp.speaker: Swag.
sp.p: Dost thou retort, in opposition stand.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Out you swaggering Rogue, Zownds Ile kicke him out of the roome. Beates him away.

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p: Out alas! their naked tooles are out,

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Feare not (sweet heart;) come along with me.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Thrice happy dayes they were, and too soone gone,
When as the heart was coupled with the tongue,
And no deceitfull flattery or guile:
Hung on the Louers teare-commixed smile:
Could women learne but that imperiousnesse,
By which men vse to stint our happinesse,
When they haue purchast vs for to be theirs,
By customarie sighs and forced teares,
To giue vs bittes of kindnesse lest we faint,
But no aboundance, that we euer want,
And still are begging; which too well they know
Endeeres affection, and doth make it grow:
Had we these sleights, how happy were we then,
That we might glory ouer loue-sicke men?
But Arts we know not; nor haue any skill,
To faine a sowre looke to a pleasing will, Enter Ioyes.
Nor cowch a secret loue in shew of hate:
But if we like, must be compassionate;
Yet I will striue to bridle and conceale,
The hid affection which my heart doth feele.

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p: Now the boy with the Bird-bolt be praisde: nay faith sister forward, t'was an excellent passion, come let's heare, what is hee? if hee be a proper man, and haue a blacke eye, a smooth chinne, and a curld pare, take him wench, if my father will not consent, runne away with him, I'le helpe to conuey you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You talke strangely sister.

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p: Sister, sister, dissemble not with me, though you doe meane to dissemble with your louer, though you haue protested to conceale your affection; by this tongue you shall not, for I'le discouer all as soone as I know the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Discouer, what will you discouer?

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p: Mary, enough Ile warrant thee, first and formost, Ile tell him thou readst loue-passions in print, and speakest euerie morning without booke to thy looking-glasse; next, that thou neuer sleep'st, till an houre after the Bell man; that as soone as thou art asleepe, thou art in a dreame, and in a dreame thou art the kindest and comfortablest bed-fellow for kissings and embracings; by this hand, I can not rest for thee, but our father.—

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p: How now! what are you two consulting on, on husbands? you thinke you loose time I am sure, but holde your owne a little Girles, it shall not be long ere I'le prouide for you: and for you Gartred, I haue bethought my selfe already,

lg.l: Whirle-pit the vsurer is late deceast,
A man of vnknowne wealth, which he has left
Vnto a prouident kinsman as I heare,
That was once seruant to that vnthrift Staines.
A prudent Gentleman they say he is,
And (as I take it) called maister Bubble.

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.l: Bubble!

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.l: Yes nimble-chappes, what say you to that?

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.l: Nothing, but that I wish his Christen name were Water.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Sir, I'm at your disposing, but my minde
Stands not as yet towards marriage,
Were you so pleasde I would a little longer
Enioy the quiet of a single bed.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.l: Heere's the right tricke of them all, let a man
Be motion'd to vm, they could be content
To leade a single life forsooth, when the harlotries
Doe pine and runne into diseases,
Eate chalke and oate-meale, cry and creep in corners,
Which are manifest tokens of their longings,
And yet they will dissemble. But Gartred,
As you doe owe me reuerence, and will pay it,
Prepare your selfe to like this Gentleman,
Who can maintaine thee in thy choice of Gownes,
Of tyres, of seruants, and of costly Iewells;
Nay for a neede, out of his easie nature,
Mai'st draw him to the keeping of a Coach
For Countrey; and Carroach for London,
Indeed what mightst thou not.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.p: Sir, here's one come from Master Bubble, to inuite you to the funerall of his vncle.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.l: Thanke the Messenger, and make him drinke,
Tell him I will not faile to wait the coarse,
Yet stay, I will goe talke with him my selfe:
Gartred, thinke vpon what I haue tolde you,
And let me er|'t be long receiue your answere.

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p: Sister, sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What say you sister?

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p: Shall I prouide a Cord?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: A Cord! what to doe?

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p:
Why to let thee out at the window; doe not I know that thou wilt runne away with the Gentleman, for whom you
made the passion, rather then indure this same Bubble, that my father talkes of, t'were good you would let mee bee of your councell, lest I breake the necke of your plot.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Sister, know I loue thee,
And I'le not thinke a thought thou shalt not know;
I loue a Gentleman that answeres me,
In all the rites of loue as faithfully,
Has woo'd me oft with Sonets, and with teares,
Yet I seeme still to slight him. Experience tells,
The Iewell that's enioy'd is not esteem'd,
Things hardly got, are alwayes highest deem'd.

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p: You say wel sister, but it is not good to linger out too long, continuance of time will take away any mans stomacke i'th world; I hope the next time that he comes to you, I shall see him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p: Why goe to then, you shall haue my opinion of him, if he deserue thee, thou shalt delay him no longer; for if you can not finde in your heart to tell him you loue him, I'le sigh it out for you; come, we little creatures must helpe one another.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: How cheerefully things looke in this place,
Tis alwayes Spring-time heere, such is the grace
And potencie of her who has the blisse,
To make it still Elizeum where she is:
Nor doth the King of flames in's golden fires,
After a tempest answer mens desires,
When as he casts his comfortable beames,
Ouer the flowrie fields and siluer streames,
As her illustrate Beautie strikes in me,
And wrappes my soule vp to felicitie.

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p: Doe you heare sir?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why sister, what will you doe?

sp.speaker: Ioyce
sp.p:
By my mayden-head, an oath which I ne'r tooke in vaine, either goe downe and comfort him, or I'le call him vp,
and disclose all: What, will you haue no mercie? but let a proper man, that might spend the spirit of his youth vpon your selfe, fall into a consumption, for shame sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Y'are the strangest creature, what would you haue me doe?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Marry, I would haue you goe to him, take him by the hand, and grype him, say y'are welcome, I loue you with all my heart, you are the man must doe the feat, and take him about the necke, and kisse vpon the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Fie how you talke, 'tis meere immodestie,
The common'st strumpet would not doe so much.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Mary the better, for such as are honest,
Should still doe what the common strumpet will not:
Speake, will you doe it?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Ile loose his company for euer first.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Doe you heare sir? heere's a Gentlewoman would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why sister, pray sister.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: One that loues you with all her heart, yet is asham'd to confesse it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Good sister hold your tongue, I will goe downe to him.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Doe not ieast with me, for by this hand I'le eyther get him vp, or goe downe my selfe, and reade the whole History of your loue to him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: If youle forbeare to call, I will goe downe.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Let me see your backe then, and heare you? doe not vse him scuruily you were best; vnset all your tyrannical looks, and bid him louingly welcome, or as I liue, I'le stretch out my voice againe; vds foot, I must take some paines I see, or wee shall neuer haue this geare cotton: but to say truth, the fault is in my melancholy Monsieur, for if hee had but halfe so much spirit, as he has flesh, hee might ha boorded her by this. But see, yonder she marches; now a passion of his side of halfe an houre long, his hatte is off already, as if he were begging one poore penny-worth of kindnesse. Enter Gart.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Shall I presume (faire Mistris) on your hand to lay my vnworthy lip?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Fie vpon him, I am asham'd to heare him, you shall haue a Country fellow at a Maie-pole, go better to his worke: he had neede to be constant, for hee is able to spoile as many Maides as he shall fall in loue withall.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir, you professe loue vnto me, let me intreate you it may appeare but in some small request.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let me know it (Lady) and I shall soone effect it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: But for this present to forbeare this place,
Because my father is expected heere.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am gone Lady.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Doe you heare sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Did you call?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Looke vp to the window.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What say you Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay pray sir goe, it is my sister call's to hasten you.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: I call to speake with you, pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The Gentlewoman has something to say to me.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: She has nothing, I doe coniure you, as you loue me, stay not. Exit Ioyce.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The power of Magicke can not fasten me, I am gone.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Good sir, looke backe no more, what voice ere call you,
Imagine, going from me, you were comming,
And vse the same speede, as you loue my safety. Exit Ger.
Wilde witted sister, I haue preuented you,
I will not haue my loue yet open'd to him,
By how much longer 'tis ere it be knowne, Enter Ioyce.
By so much dearer 'twill be when 'tis purchast:
But I must vse my strength to stop her iourney,
For she will after him: and see, she comes;
Nay sister, you are at furdest.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Let me goe you were best, for if you wrastle with me I shall throw you, passion, come backe, foole, louer, turne againe, and kisse your belly full;
sp.l: For heere she is will stand you, doe your worst:
Will you let me goe?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes, if youle stay.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: If I stirre a foote, hang me, you shall come together of your selues, and be naught, doe what you will, for if ''ere I trouble my selfe againe, let me want help In such a case when I need.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay but pre thee sister be not angry.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: I will be angry, vdsfoot, I cannot indure such foolerie, I, two bashfull fooles that would couple together, and yet ha not the faces.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay pre thee sweete sister.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Come, come, let me goe, birds that want the vse of reason and speach, can couple together in one day, and yet you that haue both, cannot conclude in twenty.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why what good would it doe you to tell him?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Doe not talke to me, for I am deafe to any thing you say, goe weepe and crie.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay but sister. Exeunt ambo.

div.stage: Enter Staines, and a Drawer with wine.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Drawer, bid them make haste at home,
Tell them they are comming from church.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I will sir. Exit Drawer.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
That I should liue to be a seruing-man, a fellow which scalds his mouth with another mans porredge, brings vp meat for other mens bellies, and carries away the bones for his own, changes his cleane trenchor for a fowle one, and is glad of it, and yet did I neuer liue so merry a life, when I was my masters master, as now I doe, being man to my man, and I will stand too't for all my former speeches, a seruing-man liues a better life then his Master, and thus I prooue it; the saying is, The nearer the bone the sweeter the flesh: then must the seruing-man needes eate the sweeter flesh, for hee alwayes pickes the bones. And againe the Prouerb sayes, The deeper the sweeter: There has the seruing-man the vantage againe, for he drinks still in the bottome of the pot, hee filles his belly, and neuer
askes what's to pay? weares broad-cloth, and yet dares walke Watling-streete, without any feare of his Draper: and for his coloure, they are according to the season, in the Summer hee is apparrelled (for the most part) like the heauens, in blew, in the winter, like the earth, in freeze.
sp.stage: Enter Bubble, sir Lionell, and Long-field and Sprinckle.

lg.l: But see, I am preuented in my Encomium,
I could haue maintained this theame these two houres.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Well, God rest his soule, hee's gone, and we must all follow him

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I, I, hee's gone sir Lionell, hee's gone.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p: Why tho he be gone, what then? 'tis not you that can fetch him againe, with all your cunning, it must bee your comfort, that he died well.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Truly and so it is, I would to God I had eene another vnckle that would die no worse; surely I shall weepe againe, if I should find my handkercher.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now! what, are these onions?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I, I, sir Lyonell, they are my onions, I thought to haue had them roasted this morning for my cold: Geruase you haue not wept to day, pray take your onions Gentlemen, the remembrance of death is sharpe, therefore there is a banquet within to sweeten your conceits: I pray walke in Gentlemen, walke you in, you know I must needes be melancholie, and keepe my Chamber, Geruase, vsher them into the banquet.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I shall sir, please you sir Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.l: Well Master Bubble, wee'le goe in and taste of your bountie.
In the meane time, you must be of good cheere.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: If griefe take not away my stomacke,
I will haue good cheere I warrant you Sprinckle.

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Had the women puddings to their dole?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And how did they take them?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Why with their hands, how should they take vm?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: O thou Hercules of ignorance! I mean, how were they satisfied?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: By my troth sir, but so so, and yet some of them had two.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: O insatiable women! whom two puddings would not satisfie, but vanish Sprinckle; bidde your fellow Geruase come hither: Exit Sprinckle.

lg.l: And off my mourning roabes, griefe to the graue,
For I haue golde, and therefore will be braue:
In silkes I'le rattle it of euery colour,
And when I goe by water, scorne a Sculler,
In blacke carnation veluet I will cloake me, Enter Staines.
And when men bid God saue mee, Cry Tu quoque:
It is needefull a Gentleman should speake Latine sometimes, is it not Geruase?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: O very gracefull sir, your most accomplish't Gentlemen are knowne by it.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Why then will I make vse of that little I haue,
Vpon times and occasions, heere Geruase, take this bag,
sp.p: And runne presently to the Mercers, buy me seuen ell, of horse flesh colour'd taffata, nine yards of yellow sattin, and eight yards of orenge tawney veluet; then runne to the Tailers, the Haberdashers, the Sempsters, the Cutlers, the Perfumers, and to all trades whatsoe'r that belong to the making vp of a Gentleman; and amongst the rest, let not the Barber bee forgotten: and looke that hee be an excellent fellow, and one that can snacke his fingers with dexteritie.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I shall fit you sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Doe so good Geruase, it is time my beard were corrected, for it is growne so sawsie, as it beginnes to play with my nose.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Your nose sir must indure it: for it is in part the fashion.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is it in fashion? why then my nose shall indure it, let it tickle his worst.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why now y'are ith right sir, if you will be a true Gallant, you must beare things resolute, as this sir, if you be at an Ordinary, and chance to loose your money at play, you must not fret and fume, teare cardes, and fling away dice, as your ignorant gamster, or country-Gentleman does, but you must put on a calme temperate action, with a kind of carelesse smile, in contempt of Fortune, as not being able with all her engins to batter down one peece of your estate, that your means may be thought inuincible, neuer tell your money, nor what you haue wonne, nor what you haue lost: if a question be made: your answer must be, what I haue lost, I haue lost, what I haue wonne, I haue wonne, a close heart and free hand, makes a man admired, a testerne or a shilling to a seruant that brings you a glasse of beere, bindes his hands to his lippes, you shall haue more seruice of him, then his Master, hee will be more humble to you, then a Cheater before a Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Geruase, giue mee thy hand, I thinke thou hast more wit then I that am thy Master, and for this Speech onely, I doe here create thee my steward: I do long me thinkes to be at an Ordinary, to smile at Fortune, and to be bountifull: Geruase about your businesse good Geruase, whilest I goe and meditate vpon a Gentleman-like behauiour, I haue an excellent gate already Geruase, haue I not?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Hercules himselfe sir, had neuer a better gate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: But dispatch Geruase, the sattin and the veluet must be thought vpon, and the Tu quoque must not bee forgotten: for whensoeuer I giue Armes, that shall be my Motto. Exit Bub.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
What a fortune had I throwne vpon me, when I preferred my selfe into this fellowes seruice! indeede I serue my selfe, and not him, for this Golde heere is mine owne truely purchased: he has credite, and shall runne ith bookes for't, I'le carry things so cunningly, that he shall not be able to looke into my actions, my morgage I haue already got into my hands: the rent hee shall enioy a while, till his riot constraine him to sell it, which I will purchase with his owne money, I must cheate a little, I haue beene cheated vpon, therefore I hope
the world will a little the better excuse mee, what his vnckle craftily got from me, I will knauishly recouer of him, to come by it, I must vary shapes, and my first shift shall be in sattin:
sp.l: Proteus propitious be to my disguise,
And I shall prosper in my enterprise. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Spendall, Pursenet, and a boy with Rackets.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A Rubber sirra.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You shall sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: And bid those two men you said would speak with me, come in.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will sir. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Did I not play this Sett will?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Excellent well by Phaeton, by Erebus, it went as if it had cut the Line.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: God blesse you sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Master Blanke! welcome.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Here's the Gentlemans man sir has brought the mony.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Wilt please you tell sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Haue you the Bond ready master Blanke?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Tis well, Pursenet, help to tell— 10.11.22. What time haue you giuen?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: The thirteenth of the next Month.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Tis well, here's light golde.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: T'will be the lesse troublesome to carry.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You say well sir, how much hast thou tolde?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: In golde and siluer here is twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Tis right M. Spendall, I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I'le take your warrant sir, and tell no further, come let me see the Condition of this Obligation.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.l: A man may winne from him that cares not for't,
This royall Casar doth regard no Cash,
Has throwne away as much in Duckes and Drakes,
As would haue bought some 50000 Capons.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Tis very well; so, lend me your penne.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.l: This is the Captaine of braue Citizens,
The Agamemnon of all merry Greekes,
A Stukely or a Sherley for his spirit,
Bounty and Royalty to men at armes.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: You giue this as your deed.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Mary do I sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Pleaseth this Gentleman to be a witnesse.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Yes Mary shall he, Pursenet, your hand.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.l: My hand is at thy seruice, Noble Brutus.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: There's for your kindnesse master Blanke.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: For your paines.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I'le take my leaue of you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: What, must you be gone too, maister Blancke?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes indeede sir, I must to the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Farewell to both, Pursenet,
Take that twenty pounds, and giue it mistris Sweatman:
Bid her pay her Landlord and Apothecarie,
And let her Butcher and her Baker stay,
They're honest men, and I'le take order with them.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: The Butcher and the Baker then shall stay.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: They must till I am somewhat stronger purst.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: If this be all, I haue my errand perfect. Exit Purs.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Heere sirra, heere's for balls, there's for your selfe.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I thanke your worship.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Commend me to your mistris. Exit Spend.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I will sir; in good faith 'tis the liberall'st Gentleman that comes into our Court, why he cares no more for a shilling then I doe for a box o'th eare, God blesse him. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Staines Gallant, Long-field and a Seruant.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Sirra, what a clocke i'st?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Past tenne sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Heere will not be a Gallant seene this houre.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Within this quarter sir, and lesse, they meete heere as soone as at any Ordinary i'th towne.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Hast any Tobacco?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Fill.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why thou report'st miracles, things not to be beleeued: I protest to thee, had'st thou not vnrip't thy selfe to me, I should neuer haue knowne thee.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I tell you true sir, I was so farre gone, that desperation knocked at mine elbow, and whispered newes to mee out of Barbarie.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Well, I'm glad so good an occasion staid thee at home,
And mai'st thou prosper in thy proiect, and goe on,
With best successe of thy inuention.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: False dice say Amen, for that's my induction,
I do meane to cheat to day without respect of persons:
When sawest thou Will Rash?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This morning at his Chamber, helle be heere.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why then doe thou giue him my name and character, for my aime is wholy at my worshipfull Master.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nay thou shalt take another into him, one that laughs out his life in this Ordinary, thankes any man that winnes his money; all the while his money is loosing, he sweares by the crosse of this siluer, and when it is gone, hee changeth it to the hilts of his sword.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Hee'le be an excellent coach-horse for my captaine.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Saue you Gallants, saue you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How think ye now? haue I not caru'd him out to you?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Th'ast lighted me into his heart, I see him throughly.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Ninni-hammer.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Take my cloake and rapier also: I thinke it be early Gentlemen, what time doe you take it to be?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Inclining to eleuen sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Inclining! a good word; I would it were inclining to twelue, for by my stomacke it should be high Noone: but what shall we doe Gallants? shall we to cardes, till our Company come?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Please you sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Harry. fetch sir Cardes, me thinkes 'tis an vnseemely fight to see Gentlemen stand idle, please you to impart your smoake.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Very willingly sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: In good faith a pipe of excellent vapour.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: The best the house yeeldes.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Had you it in the house? I had thought it had beene your owne: 'tis not so good now as I tooke it to be: Come Gentlemen, what's your game?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why Gleeke, that's your onely game.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Gleeke let it be, for I am perswaded I shall gleeke some of you; cut sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What play we, twelue pence gleeke.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Twelue pence, a crowne; vds foote I will not spoile my memory for twelue pence.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Honnor.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: What ist, Harts?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The King, what say you?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You must speake sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Why I bid thirteene.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Foureteene.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Fifteene.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Sixteene.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Sixteene, seuenteene.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: You shal ha't for me.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Eighteene.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Take it to you sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Vdslid I'le not be out-brau'd.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I vie it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I'le none of it.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Giue me a mournauall of aces, and a gleek of queens.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And me a gleeke of knaues.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Vdslid, I am gleek't this time. Enter Will Rash.

sp.speaker: Stay.
sp.p: Play.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Equall fortunes befall you Gallants.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Will Rash, well, I pray see what a vile game I haue

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: What's your game, Gleeke?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes faith, Gleek, and I haue not one Court carde, but the knaue of Clubbes.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Thou hast a wilde hand indeed: thy small cardes shew like a troupe of rebelles, and the knaue of Clubbes their chiefe Leader.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: And so they doe as God saue me, by the crosse of this siluer he sayes true. Enter Spendall.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Pray, play sir:

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Honnor.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How goe the stockes Gentlemen, what's won or lost?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: This is the first game.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes this is the first game, but by the crosse of this siluer heere's all of fiue pounds.

sp.speaker: Spend,
sp.p: Good day to you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Francke, welcome by this hand, how dost lad?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: And how does thy wench yfaith.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Why fat and plump
Like thy geldings: thou giu'st them both good prouender
It seemes, go to, thou art one of the madd'st wagges,
Of a Cittizen 'ith towne, the whole company talkes of thee already.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Talke, why let vm talke, vdsfoot I pay scot and lot, and all manner of dueties else, as well as the best of vm: it may be they vnderstand I keepe a whoore, a horse, and a kennell of hownds, what's that to them? no mans purse opens for't but mine owne; and so long, my hownds shall eate flesh, my horse bread, and my whore weare veluet.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why there spoke a courageous Boy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Vdsfoote, shall I be confin'd all the dayes of my life to walke vnder a pent-house? no, I'le take my pleasure whiles my youth affoords it.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: By the crosse of these hilts, I'le neuer play at Gleeke againe, whilst I haue a nose on my face,
I smell the knauery of the game.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why what's the matter? who has lost?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Mary that haue I, by the hiltes of my sword, I haue lost forty crowns, in as small time almost, as while a man might tell it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Change your Game for dice,
We are a full number for Nouum.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: With all my heart, where's M. Ambush the Broaker Ninni-hammer?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Go to M. Ambush, and bid him send me twenty marks vpon this Diamond. Enter Bubble.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Looke you (to make vs the merrier) who comes here.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: A fresh Gamster, M. Bubble, God saue you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tu quoque sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: God saue you Maister Bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Saue you sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Good maister Bubleb

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Is your name Master Bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Maister Bubble is my name, sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: God saue you sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: I would be better acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And I with you.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Pray let vs salute againe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: With all my heart sir.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Behold yonder the oke and the Iuy how they imbrace.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Excellent acquaintance, they shall be the Gemini.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Shall I desire your name sir?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Maister Scattergood.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Of the Scattergoods of London?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: No indeed sir, of the Scattergoods of Hampshire.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Good Maister Scattergood.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, heere's dice.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Please you aduance to the Table?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No indeede sir.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Pray will you goe?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will goe sir ouer the whole world for your sake, But in curtesie I will not budge a foote. Enter Ninnihammer.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.l: Heere is the Cash you sent me for, and master Rash,
Heere is a Letter from one of your sisters.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I haue the dice, set Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: From which sister?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: From the mad-cap, I know by the hand.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: For me, six.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: And six that.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Nine; 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8: eighteene shillings.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What's yours sir?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Mine's a Bakers dozen: master Bubble tel your mony.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: In good faith I am but a simple Gamster, and doe not know what to doe.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Why you must tell your money, and hee'le pay you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My mony! I do know how much my mony is, but he shall not pay me, I haue a better conscience then so: what for throwing the dice twice, yfaith he should haue but a hard bargaine of it.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Witty rascall, I must needes away.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why the louers can not agree, thou shalt along with me, and know all.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: But first let mee instruct thee in the condition of this Gentleman, whom dost thou take him to be?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Nay, hee's a stranger, I know him not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: By this light but you doe, if his beard were off, 'tis Staines.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: The diuell it is as soone: and what's his purpose in this disguise?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why cheating, doe you not see how he playes vpon his worshipfull Maister, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: By my faith he drawes apace.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A pox vpon these dice, giue's a fresh bale.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p:
Ha ha, the dice are not to be blamed, a man may perceiue
this is no Gentlemanly gamster, by his chasing: do you heare, my friend, fill me a glasse of beere, and ther's a shilling for your paines.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Your worship shall sir.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why how now Franke, what hast lost?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Fifteene pounds and vpwards: is there neuer an honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: What doe you lacke money sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, canst furnish me?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Vpon a sufficient pawne sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You know my shop, bid my man deliuer you a piece of three pile veluet, and let me haue as much money as you dare aduenture vpon't.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: You shall sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: A pox of this lucke, it will not last euer:
Play sir, I'le set you.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Franke, better fortune befa'l thee: and Gentlemen, I must take my leaue, for I must leaue you.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Must you needes be gone?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Indeede I must.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes truely.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: At your discretions Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Farewell. Exeunt Rash & Long.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Cry you mercy sir, I am chanc'd with you all Gentlemen: heere I haue 7, heere 7, and heere 10.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: T'is right sir, and ten that.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And nine that.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Two fiues at all. Drawes all.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: One and fiue that.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Vmh, and can a suite of Sattin cheate so grossely? By this light there's nought on one die but fiues and sixes, I must not be thus gull'd.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Come Maister Spendall, set.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No sir, I haue done.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Why then let vs all leaue, for I thinke dinner's neare ready.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Your meat's vpon the Table.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: On the Table! come Gentlemen, we do our stomackes wrong: M. Bubble, what haue you lost?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: That's no matter, what I haue lost, I haue lost; nor can I chuse but smile at the foolishnes of the dice.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I am but your steward Gentlemen, for after dinner I may restore it againe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: M. Scatter-good, will you walke in?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: I'le wait vpon you sir, come Gentlemen, will you follow? Exit: manent Spendall & Staines.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Yes sir, I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Heare you sir, a word.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Ten if you please.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I haue lost fifteene pounds.

sp.speaker: Sta
sp.p: And I haue found it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: You say right, found it you haue indeed,
But neuer wonne it: doe you know this die?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: You seeme a Gentleman, and you may perceiue.
I haue some respect vnto your credite,
To take you thus aside, will you restore
What you ha drawne from me vnlawfully?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Sirra, by your out-side you seeme a cittizen,
Whose Cockes-comb, I were apt enough to breake,
But for the Lawe; goe y'are a prating Iacke,
Nor 'ist your hopes, of crying out for clubbes,
Can saue you from my chasticement, if once
You shall but dare to vtter this againe.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You lie, you dare pot.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Lie! nay villaine, now thou tempest me to thy death.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: So 't, you must buy it dearer,
The best bloud flowes within you is the price.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Darst thou resist, thou art no Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I am a Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Say thou arte a Gentleman, and I am satisfied,
For then I know thou'lt answer me in field.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Ile say directly what I am, a Citizen,
And I will meete thee in the field as fairely
As the best Gentleman that weares a sword.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I accept it, the meeting place.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Beyond the Maze in Tuttle.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: What weapon?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Single rapier.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The time.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: To morrow.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The houre.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Twixt nine and ten.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Tis good, I shall expect you, farewell. Ex. omnes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Farewell sir.

div.stage: Enter Will Rash, Long-field, and Ioyce.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why I commend thee Gerle, thou speak'st as thou thinkst, thy tongue and thy heart are Relatiues, and thou wert not my sister, I should at this time fall in love with thee.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: You should not need, for and you were not my brother, I should fall in loue with you, for I loue a proper man with my heart, and so does all the Sex of vs, let my sister dissemble neuer so much, I am out of charity with these nice and squemish tricks, we were borne for men, and men for vs, and wee must together.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: This same plaine dealing is a Iewell in thee.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: And let mee enioy that Iewell, for I loue plaine dealing with my heart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Tha'rt a good wench yfaith, I should neuer be ashamed to call thee sister, though thou shouldst marry a Broomeman: but your louer me thinkes is ouer tedious.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: No, looke ye sir, could you wish a man to come better vpon his q, let vs withdraw.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Close, close, for the prosecution of the plot, wench,
See he prepares.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.l: The Sunne is yet wrapt in Auroraes armes,
And lull'd with her delight, forgets his creatures:
Awake thou god of heate,
I call thee vp, and taske thee for thy slownesse;
Poynt all thy beames through yonder flaring glasse,
And raise a beauty brighter then thy selfe; Musicke.
Musitions, giue to each Instrument a tongue,
To breathe sweete musicke in the eares of her
To whom I send it as a messenger. Enter Gartred aloft.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir, your musicke is so good, that I must say I like it; but the Bringer so ill welcome, that I could be content to loose it: if you plaid for mony, there 'tis; if for loue, heere's none; if for goodwill, I thanke you, and when you will you may be gone,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Leaue me not intranc'd: sing not my death,
Thy voyce is able to make Satires tame,
And call rough windes to her obedience.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir, sir, our eares itch not for flattery, heere you besiege my window, that I dare not put forth my selfe to take the gentle Ayre, but you are in the fieldes, and volley out your woes, your plaints, your loues, your iniuries.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Since you haue heard, and know them, giue redresse, True beauty neuer yet was mercilesse.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir, rest thus satisfied, my minde was neuer woman, neuer alter'd, nor shall it now beginne: So fare you well. Exis Gart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Sfoot, she playes the terrible tyrannizing Tamberlaine ouer him, this it is to turne Turke, from a most absolute compleate Gentleman, to a most absurd ridiculous and fond louer.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Oh, when a woman knowes the power and authoritie of her eie.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Fie vpon her, shee's good for nothing then, no more then a iade that knowes his owne strength: The windowe is clasped, now brother, pursue your proiect, and deliuer your friend from the tyranny of my domineering sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Doe you heare, you drunkard in loue, come in to
vs and be ruled, you would little thinke, that the wench that talked so scuruily out of the window there, is more inamored on thee then thou on her: nay, looke you now, see if hee turne not away slighting our good councell: I am no Christian if shee doe not sigh, whine, and grow sicke for thee: looke you sir, I will bring you in good witnesse against her.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Sir, y'are my brothers friend, and I'le be plaine with you, you doe not take the course to winne my sister, but indirectly goe about the bush: you come and fiddle heere, and keepe a coile in verse: holde off your hatte, and beg to kisse her hand, which makes her prowd. But to bee short, in two lines thus it is:
sp.l: Who most doth loue, must seeme most to neglect it,
For those that shew most loue, are least respected.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: A good obseruation by my faith.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well this instruction comes too late now,
Stand you close, and let me prosecute my inuention,
Sister, O sister, wake, arise sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: How now brother, why call you with such terrour?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: How can you sleepe so sound, and heare such groanes,
So horride and so tedious to the eare,
That I was frighted hither by the sound?
O sister, heere lies a Gentleman that lou'd you too deerely,
And himselfe too ill, as by his death appeares,
I can report no further without teares;
Assist me now.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: When he came first, death startled in his eyes,
His hand had not forsooke the dagger hilt,
But still he gaue it strength, as if he feard
He had not sent it home vnto his heart.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Enough, enough,
If you will haue me liue, giue him no name,
Suspition tells me 'tis my Geraldine:
But be it whom it will, I'le come to him,
To suffer death as resolute as he. Exit Gart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Did not I tell you 'twould take, downe sir downe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I ghesse what y'ould haue me doe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: O for a little bloud to besprinckle him.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: No matter for blood, I'le not suffer her to come neare him, till the plot haue tane his full height.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A scarffe ore my face, left I betray my selfe.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Heere, heere, lie still, she comes,
Now Mercurie, be propitious.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Where lies this spectacle of blood?
This tragicke Sceane.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Yonder lies Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: O let me see him with his face of death!
Why doe you stay me from my Geraldine?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Because, vnworthy as thou art, thou shalt not see
The man now dead, whom liuing thou didst scorne,
The worst part that he had, deseru'd thy best,
But yet contemn'd, deluded, mock'd, despisde by you,
Vnfit for aught but for the generall marke
Which you were made for, mans creation.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Burst not my heart before I see my Loue,
Brother, vpon my knees I begge your leaue,
That I may see the wound of Geraldine,
I will embalme his body with my teares,
And carry him vnto his sepulcher,
From whence I'le neuer rise, but be interr'd
In the same dust he shall be buried in.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I doe protest shee drawes sad teares from me,
I pre thee let her see her Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Brother, if e're you lou'd me as a sister,
Depriue me not the sight of Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well, I am contented you shall touch his lippes,
But neither see his face nor yet his wound,

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Not see his face?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Nay, I haue sworne it to the contrary:
Nay, harke you further yet.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: But one kisse, no more.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Why then no more.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Marry this liberty I'le giue you,
If you intend to make my speach of repentance
Ouer him, I am content, so it be short.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: What you command is Law, and I obey.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.l: Peace, giue eare to the passion.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Before I touch thy body, I implore
Thy discontented ghost to be appeasde:
Send not vnto me till I come my selfe:
Then shalt thou know how much I honor'd thee.
O see the colour of his corall lippe!
Which in despight of death liues full and fresh,
As when he was the beauty of his Sex:
T'were sinne worthy the worst of plagues to leaue thee:
Not all the strength and pollicie of man
Shall snatch me from thy bosome.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Looke, looke, I thinke shee'l rauish him.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Why how now sister?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Shall we haue both one graue? here I am chain'd,
Thunder nor Earthquakes shall shake me off.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: No? I'le try that, come dead man, awake, vp with your bag and baggage, and let's haue no more fooling.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: And liue's my Geraldine?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Liue? faith I,
Why should he not? he was neuer dead,
That I know on.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is no wonder Geraldine should liue,
Tho he had emptied all his vitall spirites,
The Lute of Orpheus spake not halfe so sweete,
When he descended to th'infernall vaults,
To fetch againe his faire Euridice,
As did thy sweete voyce to Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: I'le exercise that voyce, since it doth please
My better selfe, my constant Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.l: Why so la, heere's an end of an old Song,
Why could not this haue beene done before
I pray?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: O y'are a goodly sister, this is your plot:
Well, I shall liue one day to requite you.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Spare me not, for wheresoeuer I set my affection, although it be vpon a Colliar, if I fall backe, vnlesse it bee in the right kinde, binde mee to a stake, and let mee be burned to death with char-coale.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Well, thou art a mad wench, and there's no more to be done at this time, but as wee brought you together, so to part you, you must not lie at racke and manger: there be those within, that will forbid the banes, Time must shake good Fortune by the hand, before you two must be great, specially you sister; come leaue swearing.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Must we then part?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Must you part? why how thinke you? vdsfoote, I do thinke we shall haue as much to do to get her from him, as we had to bring her to him: this loue of women is of a strange qualitie, and has more trickes then a Iuggler.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: But this, and then farewell.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Thy company is heauen, thy absence hell.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Lord who'ld thinke it?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Come wench. Exeunt omnes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: This ground is firme and euen, I'le goe no further.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: This be the place then, and prepare you sir,
You shall haue faire play for your life of me,
For looke sir, I'le be open breasted to you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Shame light on him that thinkes his safety lieth in a
French doublet.
Nay I would strippe my selfe, would comelinesse
Giue sufferance to the deed, and fight with thee,
As naked as a Mauritanian Moore.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Giue me thy hand, by my heart I loue thee,
Thou art the highest spirited Cittizen,
That euer Guild-hall tooke notice of.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Talke not what I am, vntill you haue tried me.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Come on sir. They fight.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Now sir, your life is mine.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Why then take it, for I'le not begge it of thee.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Nobly resolu'd, I loue thee for those words,
Heere take thy armes againe, and if thy malice
Haue spent it selfe like mine, then let vs part
More friendly then we met at first incounter.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Sir, I accept this gift of you, but not your friendship,
Vntill I shall recouer't with my honour.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Will you fight againe then?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Faith thou dost well then, iustly to whip my folly.
But come sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Hold, y'are hurt I take it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Hurt! where? zownds I feele it not.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: You bleed I am sure.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Sblood, I thinke you weare a cattes claw vpon your
Rapiers point,
I am scratcht indeed, but small as 'tis,
I must haue blood for blood.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Y'are bent to kill I see.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: No by my hopes, if I can seape that sinne,
And keepe my good name, I'le neuer offer't.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Well sir, your worst.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: We both bleed now I take it,
And if the motion may be equall thought,
To part with clasp'd hands: I shall first subscribe.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: It were vnmanlinesse in me to refuse
The safety of vs both, my hand shall neuer fall
From such a charitable motion.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Then ioyne we both, and heere our malice ends,
Tho foes we came to'th field, wee'l depart frends. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir Lyonell and a Seruant.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Come, come, follow me knaue, follow me, I haue the best nose 'ith house, I thinke, either wee shall haue rainie weather, or the vaults vnstop'd: sirra, goe see, I would not haue my guesse smell out any such inconuenience: Doe you heare sirra Symon?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Bid the Kitchin-maide skowre the sincke, and make cleane her backe-side, for the wind lies iust vpon't.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: And bid Anthonie put on his white fustian doublet, for hee must wait to day: It doth mee so much good to stirre and talke, to place this, and displace that, that I shall neede no Apothecaries prescriptions, I haue sent my daughter this morning as farre as Pimliko to fetch a draught of Darby ale, that it may fetch a colour in her cheekes, the puling harlotrie looks so pale, and it is all for want of a man, for so their mother would say, God rest her soule, before she died. Exit Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, the Gentlemen are come already.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How knaue, the Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes sir, yonder they are.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p: Gods pretious, we are too tardie, let one be sent presently to meete the gerles, and hasten their comming home quickely: how dost thou stand dreaming? Gentlemen, I see you loue me, you are carefull of your houre; you may be deceiued in your cheare, but not in your welcome.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Thankes, and Tu quoque is a word for all.

sp.speaker: Scatterg.
sp.p: A pretty concise roome: sir Lyonell, where are your danghters?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: They are at your service sir, and forth comming.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Gods will Geruase! how shall I behaue my selfe to the Gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why aduance your selfe toward them, with a comely steppe, and in your salute, be carefull you strike not too high, nor too lowe, and afterward for your discourse, your Tu quoque will beare you out.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, and that be all, I care not, for I'le set a good face on't, that's flat: and for my neather parts, let them speake for themselues: here's a legge, and euer a Baker in England shew me a better, I'le giue him mine for nothing.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: O that's a speciall thing that I must caution you of.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What sweete Geruase?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why for commending your selfe; neuer whilest you line commend your selfe: and then you shall haue the Ladies themselues commend you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I would they would else.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why they will I'le assure you sir, and the more vilely you speake of your selfe, the more will they striue to collaud you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Let me alone to dispraise my selfe,
I'le make my selfe the arrantest Cockes-combe within a whole
Countrey.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.l: Heere come the Gipsies, the Sunne-burn'd gerles,
Whose beauties will not vtter them alone,
They must haue bagges although my credite cracke for't.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Is this the eldest sir?

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.l: Yes marry is she sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I'le kisse the yongest first, because she likes me best.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Marry sir, and whilest you are there, I'le be heere:
O delicious touch! I thinke in conscience
Her lippes are lined quite through with Orenge Tawny veluet.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: They kisse exceeding well, I doe not thinke but they haue beene brought vp too't, I will beginne to her like a Gentleman in a set speech: Faire Ladie, shall I speake a word with you?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: With you Lady,— this way,— a litle more,—
So now tis well, vmh—
Euen as a Drummer,— or a Pewterer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Which of the two no matter,
For one beates on a Drumme, tother a Platter.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: In good fayth sweet Lady you say true:
But pray marke me further, I will begin againe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I pray Sir doe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Euen as a Drummer, as I sayd before,—
Or as a Pewterer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Doo— doo— doo.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: What doe they doo?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: By my troth Lady, I doe not know: for to say truth, I am a kind of an Asse.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: How Sir, an Asse?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes indeed Lady.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Nay that you are not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: So God ha mee, I am Lady: you neuer saw an arranter Asse in your life.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Why heer's a Gentleman your friend, will not say so.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Y fayth but he shall: How say you sir,
Am not I an Asse?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Yes by my troth Lady is he: Why Ile say any thing my brother Bubble sayes.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Is this the man my Father choose for mee, to make a Husband of? O God, how blind are parents in our loues: so they haue wealth, they care not to what thinges they marry vs.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray looke vpon mee Lady.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: So I doe sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I but looke vpon mee well, and tell mee if you euer saw any man looke so scuruily, as I doe?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: The fellow sure is frantique.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: You doe not marke mee?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I, but looke vpon mee well:
Did you euer see a worse timberd Legge?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: By my fayth tis a pretty foure square Legge.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I but your foure square Legges are none of the best.
Oh! Iaruis, Iaruis.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Excellent well sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What say you now to mee Lady, can you find ere a good inch about mee?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yes that I can sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Find it, and take it sweete Lady:
There I thinke I bobd her, Iaruis?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Well sir, disparadge not your selfe so: for if you were
The man you'd make your selfe; yet out of your
Behauiour and discourse, I could find cause enough
To loue you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
