sp.p: Augh! now shee comes to mee: My behauiour? alas, alas, tis clownicall; and my discourse is very bald, bald: You shall not heare mee breake a good Ieast in a twelue month.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: No sir? why now you breake a good Ieast.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: No, I want the Boone Ioure, and the Tu quoques,
Which yonder Gentleman has: Ther's a bob for him too:
There's a Gentleman, and you talke of a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Who hee? hee's a Coxcombe indeed.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: We are sworne Brothers in good fayth Lady.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Yes in truth wee are sworne Brothers, and do meane to goe both alike, and to haue Horses alike.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: And they shall be sworne Brothers too?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: If it please them, Lady.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: M. Ballance, the Gold smith desires to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Bid him come, knaue.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: I woonder (Sir Lyonell) your sonne Will Rash is not heere?

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Is hee of your acquaintance, sir?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
O very familiar; hee strooke mee a boxe on the eare
once, and from thence grew my loue to him.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: It was a signe of vertue in you sir; but heele be heere at dinner. Maister Ballance, what makes you so strange?
Come, you're welcome: what's the Newes?

sp.speaker: Balla.
sp.l: Why sir, the old Newes: your man Francis royots still,
And little hope of thrift there is in him;
Therefore I come to aduise your Worship,
To take some order whilst there's something left,
The better part of his best Ware's consumd.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Speake softly Maister Ballance.
But is there no hope of his recouerie?

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.p: None at all sir; for hees already layd to be arested by some that I know.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Well, I doe suffer for him, and am loath
Indeed to doe, what I am constraind to doe:
Well sir, I meane to ceaze on what is left.
And harke you one word more.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: What haynous sinne has yonder man committed,
To haue so great a punishment, as waite
vpon the humors of an idle Foole:
A very proper Fellow, good Legge, good Face,
A Body well proportiond: but his minde
Bewrayes he neuer came of Generous kinde.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Goe to, no more of this at this time.
What sir, are you come?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Yes sir, and haue made bold to bring a Guift along.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Maister Geraldines sonne of Essex?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The same sir.

sp.speaker: Lyo
sp.p: Ye're welcom sir, when wil your Father be in towne?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: T'will not be long, sir.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: I shall be glad to see him when he coms.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: In the meane time you're welcome; pray be not strange,
Ile leaue my Sonne amongst you Gentlemen,
I haue some busines: harke you M. Ballance,
Dinner will soone be readie; one word more. Exit Lyo. & Bal.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: And how does my little Asinus and his Tu quoque here? Oh you pretty sweet-fac'd rogues, that for your countenances might be Alexander and Lodwicke: What sayes the old man to you? wil't be a match? shall wee call Brothers?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: I fayth with all my heart; if Mistris Gartred will, wee will be married to morrow.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: S'fott, if Mistris Ioyce will, wee'le be married to night.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why you couragious Boyes, and worthy Wenches, made out of Waxe. But what shall's doe when wee haue dinde, shall's goe see a Play?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Yes fayth Brother: if it please you, let's goe see a Play at the Gloabe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I care not; any whither, so the Clowne haue a part: For Ifayth I am no body without a Foole.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why then wee'le goe to the Red Bull; they say Green's a good Clowne.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Greene? Greene's an Asse.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Wherefore doe you say so?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Indeed I ha no reason: for they say, hee is as like mee as euer hee can looke.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Well then, to the Bull.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: A good resolution, continue it: nay on?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Not before the Gentlewomen; not I neuer.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: O while you liue, men before women:
Custome hath plac'd it so.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why then Custome is not so mannerly, as I would be.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Farewell M. Scatter-good: Come Louer, you're too busie heere, I must tutor yee: Cast not your eye at the table on each other, my Father will spie you without Spectacles,
sp.l: Hee is a shrewd obseruer: doe you heare mee?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Come then go wee togeather, let the Wenches alone.
Doe you see yonder fellow?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes: prethee what is hee?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Ile giue you him within, he must not now be thought on: but you shall know him. Exit Rash. & Gerald.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: I haue obseru'd my sister, and her eye
Is much inquisitiue after yond fellow;
Shee has examin'd him from head to foot:
Ile stay and see the issue.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: To wrastle gainst the streame of our Affection,
Is to strike Ayre, or buffet with the Winde,
That playes vpon vs: I haue striu'd to cast
This fellow from my thoughts, but still he growes
More comely in my sight; yet a slaue
Vnto one worse condition'd then a Slaue:
They are all gone, heer's none but hee, and I,
Now I will speake to him: and yet I will not.
Oh! I wrong my selfe, I will suppresse
That insurrection Loue hath traind in mee,
And leaue him as he is: once my bold spirits
Had vowed to vtter all my thoughts to him
On whom I setled my affection:
And why retyres it now?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Fight Loue on both sides; for on mee thou strik'st
Strokes that hath beat my heart into a flame:
She hath sent amorous glaunses from her eye:
Which I haue backe returnd as faythfully.
I would make to her, but these seruile Roabes,
Curbes that suggestion, till some fitter time
Shall bring mee more perswadingly vnto her.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I wonder why he stayes; I feare hee notes mee,
For I haue publiquely betrayde my selfe,
By too much gazing on him: I will leaue him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: But you shall not; Ile make you speake to him
Before you goe. Doe you heare sir?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: What meane you sister?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: To fit you in your kind, sister: doe you remember
How you once tyranizd ouer mee?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Nay prethee leaue this iesting,
I am out of the vaine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I, but I am in: goe speake to your Louer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Ile first be buried quicke.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: How, ashamd? S'fott Itro, if I had set my affection on a Collier, Ide nere fall backe, vnlesse it were in the right kind: if I did, let mee be tyed to a Stake, and burnt to death with Charcoale.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Nay then wee shall hate.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes marry shall you. Sister, will you speake to him:

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Doe you heare sir? heer's a Gentlewoman would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Why Sister, I pray Sister.

sp.speaker: Gart
sp.l: One that loues you with all her heart,
Yet is ashamd to confesse it.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Did you call, Ladyes?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: No sir, heer's no one cald.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes sir twas I, I cald to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: My Sister's somewhat frantique; there's no regard to be had vnto her clamors: Will you yet leaue?

lg.l: In fayth you'le anger mee.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Passion: Come backe foole louer, turne againe and kisse your belly full, heer's one will stand yee.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: What does this meane troe?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yes, is your humor spent?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Come let me goe, Birds that want the vse of
Reason and of Speech, can couple together in one day;
And yet you that haue both, cannot conclude in twentie:
now Sister I am euen with you, my venome is spit,
As much happinesse may you enjoy with your louer as I with mine:
And droope not wench, not neuer be ashamd of him,
The man will serue the turne, though he be wrapt
In a blew Coate, Ile warrant him, come.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You're merely disposed, Sister.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: I needs must prosper, Fortune & Loue worke for mee.
Be moderate my Ioyes; for as you grow to your full height,
So Bubbles waxeth low. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Will my sweete Spendall be gone then?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: I must vpon promise; but Ile be heere at supper:
Therefore Mistris Sweatman, provide vs some good cheare.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: The best the Market will yeeld.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Heer's twentie shillings; I protest I haue left my selfe but a Crowne, for my spending mony: for indeed I intend to be frugall, and turne good husband.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I marry will you, you'le to play againe, & loose your Monie and fall to fighting; my very heart trembles to thinke on it: how if you had been kild in the quarrell, of my fayth I had been but a dead woman.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Come, come, no more of this; thou dost but dissemble.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Dissemble? do not you say so; for if you doe,
Gods my iudge Ile giue my selfe a gash.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Away, away, prethee no more: farewell.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Nay busse first: Well,
There's no aduersitie in the world shall part vs.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Thou art a louing Rascall; farewell.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: You will not fayle supper?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You haue my word; farewell.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Sir, wee arrest you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Arrest mee, at whose suite?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Marry there's suites enough against you,
Ile warrant you.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Come, away with him.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Stay, heare mee a word.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: What doe you say?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: How now Purssuet, why com'st in such haste?

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.l: Shut vp your doores, and barre young Spendall out,
And let him be cashieard your companie,
He is turnd Banquerout, his wares are ceazd on,
And his shop shut vp.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: How, his wares ceazd on? thou dost but iest, I hope.

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.l: What this tongue doth report, these eyes haue seene,
It is no Aesops fable that I tell,
But it is true, as I am faythfull Pander.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.l: Nay I did euer thinke the prodigall would proue
A Banquerout; but hang him, let him rott
In prison, he comes no more within these doores
I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Come hither, I would he would but offer it,
Weele fier him out with a pox to him.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Will you doe it;
To carrie me to prison, but vndoes me?

sp.speaker: 1. Sar.
sp.l: What say you fellow Gripe, shall we take his 40. shillings.

sp.speaker: 2. Sar.
sp.l: Yes fayth, we shall haue him againe within this weeke.

sp.speaker: 1. Sar.
sp.l: Well Sir, your 40 shillings? and weele haue some compassion on you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Will you but walke with me vnto that house,
And there you shall receaue it.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: What, where the women are?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.l: Looke yonder, if the vngratious rascall be not comming hither,
Betwixt two Sargiantes: he thinkes belike,
That weele relieue him; let vs goe in,
And clap the doores against him.

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.l: It is the best course Mistres Tickleman?

sp.speaker: Tick
sp.l: But I say no, you shall not stirre a foote,
For I will talke with him,

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Nan, I am come
Euen in the Minute that thou didst professe
Kindnesse vnto mee, to make tryall of it,
Aduersitie thou Sees layes hands vpon mee,
But Fortie-shillings will deliuer mee,

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Why you Impudent Rogue, do you come to me for Mony?
Or do I know you? what acquaintance pray,
Hath euer past betwixt your selfe and mee?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Zounds do you mocke vs, to bring vs to these women that do not know you?

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.l: Yes in good Sooth, (Officers I take't you're)
Hee's a meere stranger heere: onely in charitie,
Sometimes we haue reliued him with a meale.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: This is not earnest in you? Come, I know
My guistes and bountie cannot be soone buried:
Goe prethee fetch Fourtie shillings?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Talke not to mee (you slaue) of Fourtie shillings;
For by this light that shines, aske it againe,
Ile send my Knife of an earrand in your Guttes:
A shamelesse Roge to come to mee for Money?

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.l: Is he your Prisoner, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Yes marry is hee.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.l: Pray carry him then to Prison, let him smart for't,
Perhaps twill tame the wildnesse of his youth,
And teach him how to lead a better life:
Hee had good counsell heere, I can assure you,
And if a would a tooke it.

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.l: I told him still my selfe, what would insew.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Furies breake loose in mee: Sargeants, let me goe, Ile giue you all I haue, to purchase freedome but for a lightning while, to teare yond Whore. Baud, Pander; and in them, the Diuell: for there's his Hell, his habitation; nor has hee any other locall place. Takes Spendals Cloake.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: No sir, weele take no Bribes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Honest Sargeants, give me leaue to vnlade
A heart ore-chargd with griefe; as I haue a soule,
Ile not breake from you.
Thou Strumpet, that wert borne to ruine men,
My fame, and fortune: be subiect to my Cursse,
And heare mee speake it: Mayst thou in thy youth,
Feele the sharpe Whippe; and in thy Beldame age,
The Cart: when thou art growne to bee
An old Vpholster vnto Venerie,
(A Bawd I meane, to liue by Fether-beds,)
Mayst-thou be driven to sell all thou hast
Vnto thy Aqua vite Bottle; that's the last
A Bawd will part withall; and line so poore,
That being turnd forth thy house, mayst die at doore.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Come sir, ha you done?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: A little further giue mee leaue, I pray,
I haue a charitable Prayer to end with.
May the French Canniball eate into thy flesh,
And picke thy bones so cleane, that the report
Of thy Calamitie, may draw resort
Of all the common Sinners in the towne,
To see thy mangled Carcasse: and that then,
They may vpon't, turne honest; Bawd, say Amen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.l: Out vpon him wicked villaine, how he blaspheames;

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.l: Hee will be damn'd for turning Heretique.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Hang him Banquerout rascall, let him talke in Prison,
The whilst weele spend his Goods: for I did neuer
Heare, that men tooke example by each other.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.l: Well, if men did rightly consider't, they should find,
That Whores and Bawdes are profitable members
In a Common-wealth: for indeed, tho wee somewhat
Impaire their Bodyes, yet wee doe good to their Soules;
For I am sure, wee still bring them to Repentance.

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.l: By Dis, and so wee doe.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: Come, come, will you Dis before: thou art one of them, that I warrant thee wilt be hangd, before thou wilt repent. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Well, this Loue is a troublesome thing, Iupiter blesse mee out of his fingers: ther's no estate can rest for him: Hee runnes through all Countries, will trauell through the Ile of Man in a minut; but neuer is quiet till hee come into Middle-sex, and there keepes his Christmas:
sp.l: Tis his habitation, his mantion, from whence,
Heele neuer out, till hee be fierd.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, do not tyranize too much, least one day he make you know his Deitie, by sending a shaft out of a sparkling eye, shall strike so deepe into your heart, that it shall make you fetch your breath short againe.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: And make mee cry, O eyes no eyes, but two celestiall Starres! A pox ont, Ide as leiue heare a fellow sing throngh the nose. How now Wench?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Keepe your station; you stand as well for the incounter as may be: shee is comming on; but as melancholy, as a Base-vyollin Consort.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Which makes thee as Sprightly as the Trebble.

Now dost thou play thy prize: heer's the honorable Sciense one against another: Doe you heare Louer, the thing is done you wot off; you shall haue your Wench alone without any disturbance: now if you can doe any good, why so, the Siluer Game be yours, weele stand by and giue ayme, and hallow if you hit the Clout.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Tis all the assistance I request of you,
Bring mee but opportunatly to her presence,
And I desire no more: and If I cannot win her,
Let mee loose her.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Well sir, let me tell you, perhaps you vndertake
A harder taske then yet you doe imagine.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: A taske, what to win a Woman, & haue opportunitie? I would that were a taske ifayth, for any man that weares his wittes about him: giue me but halfe an houres
sp.l: Conference with the coldest creature of them all,
And if I bring her not into a fooles Paradice,
Ile pul out my tongue, & hang it at her doore for a draw-latch.
Vdsfoot, I'de nere stand thrumming of Caps for the matter,
Ile quickly make tryall of her if shee loue:
To haue her Beautie prays'd, Ile prayse it: if her Witte,
Ile commende it: if her good parts, Ile exalt them.
No course shall scape me; for to what soeuer I saw her inclind too, to that would I fit her.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: But you must not doe thus to her, for shee's a subtile flouting rogue, that will laugh you out of countenance, if you solicit her seriously: No, talke me to her wantonly, slightly & carelesly, and perhaps so you may preuaile as much with her, as wind does with a Sayle, carry her whither thou wilt, Bully.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Well sir, Ile follow your instruction.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Do so. And see she appeares; fall you two off from vs,
Let vs two walke togeather.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Why did my enquiring eye take in this fellow,
And let him downe so easie to my heart;
Where like a Conquerour he ceases on it,
And beates all other men out of my Bossome?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Sister, you're well met,
Heer's a Gentleman desires to be acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: See, the Seruingman is turnd a Gentleman,
That villanous Wench my Sister, has no mercy,
Shee and my Brother has conspired together to play vpon me;
sp.p: But Ile preuent their sport: for rather then my tongue shall haue scope to speake matter to giue them mirth, my heart shall breake.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: You haue your desire sir, Ile leaue you;
Grapple with her as you can.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Lady, God saue you. She turns backe vpon the motion,
Ther's no good to be done by braying for her, I see that;
I must plunge into a passion: now for a peece of Hero and Leander: t'were excellent; and prayse be to my memorie,
It has reacht halfe a dozen lines for the purpose:
Well, shee shall haue them.
One is no Number; Maydes are nothing then
Without the sweete societie of Men.
Wilt thou liue single still? one shalt thou bee,
Though neuer singling Hymen couple thee.
Wild Sauages that drinke of running Springs,
Thinkes Water farre excells all other thing.
They that dayly taste neat Wine, despise it.
Virginitie albeit some highly prize it,
Compard with Marriage; had you tryde them both,
Differs as much, as Wine and Water doth. No?
Why then haue at you in another kind.
sp.p: By the fayth of a Souldier (Lady) I doe reuerence the ground that you walke vpon: I will fight with him that darts, say you are not faire: Stabbe him that will not pledge your health; and with a Dagger pierce a Vaine, to drinke a full health to you; but it shall be on this condition, that you shall speake first.

lg.l: Vds-foot, if I could but get her to talke once, halfe my labour were ouer: but Ile try her in an other vaine.
What an excellent creature is a Woman without a tongue?

sp.p: But what a more excellent creature is a Woman that has a tongue, and can hold her peace? But how much more excellent and fortunate a creature is that man, that has that Woman to his wife? This cannot choose but madde her;
sp.l: And if any thing make a Woman talke, tis this. It will not doe
tho yet I pray God they haue not guld mee:
But Ile try once againe.
When will that tongue take libertie to talke?
Speake but one word, and I am satisfied:
Or doe but say but Mum, and I am answerd?
No sound? no accent? Is there no noyse in Woman?
Nay then without direction I ha don.
I must goe call for helpe.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How, not speake?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Not a syllable, night nor sleepe, is not more silent:
Shee's as dumbe as Westminster Hall, in the long vacation.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well, and what would you haue mee doe?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Why, make her speake.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: And what then?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Why, let mee alone with her.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: I, so you sayd before, Giue you but opportunitie,
And let you alone, you'd desire no more: but come,
Ile try my cunning for you: See what I can doe.
How doe you Sister, I am sory to heare you are not well,
This Gent. tels mee you haue lost your tongue, I pray lels see?
If you can but make signes whereabout you lost it,
Weele goe & looke fort': in good fayth Sister, you looke very pale,
In my conscience tis for griefe: will you haue
Any comfortable Drinkes sent for, this is not the way;
Come walke, seeme earnest in discourse, cast not an eye
Towards her, and you shall see weaknesse worke it selfe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: My heart is swolne so big, that it must vent,
Or it will burst: Are you a Brother?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Looke to your selfe Sir,
The Brazen head has spoke, and I must leaue you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Has shame that power in him, to make him fly:
And dare you be so impudent to stand
Iust in the face of my incensed anger?
What are you? why doe you stay? who sent for you?
You were in Garments yesterday, befitting
A fellow of your fashion; has a Crowne
Purchast that shyning Sattin of the Brokers?
Or ist a cast Suite of your goodly Maisters.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: A Cast suite, Lady?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You thinke it does become you: fayth it does not,
A Blew Coat with a Badge, does better with you.
Goe vntrusse your Maisters Poynts, and doe not dare
To stop your Nose when as his Worship stinkes:
ta's been your breeding.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Vds'life, this is excellent: now she talkes.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Nay, were you a Gentleman: and which is more;
Well Landed, I should hardly loue you:
For, for your Face, I neuer saw a worse,
It lookes as if't were drawne with yellow Oacker
Vpon blacke Buckram: and that Haire
Thats on your Chin, lookes not like Beard,
But as ift had been smeard with Shoomakers Wax.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Vdsfoot, sheele make mee out of loue with my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: How dares your Basenes once aspyre vnto
So high a fortune, as to reach at mee:
Because you haue heard, that some haue run away
With Butlers, Horskeepers, and their fathers Clearks;
You forsooth, cockerd with your owne suggestion,
Take heart vpon't, and thinke mee, (that am meate,
And set vp for your Maister) fit for you.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: I would I could get her now to hold her tongue.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Or cause, some times as I haue past along,
And haue returnd a Curtcie for your Hatt;
You (as the common trickes is) straight suppose,
Tis Loue, (sirreuerence, which makes the word more beastly.)

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Why, tis worse then scilence.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: But wee are fooles, and in our reputations
We find the smart on't:
Kindnesse, is tearmed Lightnesse, in our sex:
And when we giue a Fauour, or a Kisse,
Wee giue our Good names too.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Will you be dumbe againe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Men you are cald, but you're a viperous brood,
Whom we in charitie take into our bosomes,
And cherish with our heart: for which, you sting vs.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Vds'foot, Ile fetch him that waked your tonge,
To lay it downe againe.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Why how now man?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: O reliue mee, or I shall loose my hearing,
You haue raysde a Furie vp into her tongue
A Parliament of women could not make
Such a Confused noyse as that she vtters.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well, what would you haue mee do?

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Why make her hold her tongue.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: And what then?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Why then let me alone againe.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: This is very good I fayth, first giue thee but oppertunitie, and let thee alone: then make her but Speake, and let
Thee alone: now make her hold her tongue, and then
Let her alone: By my torth I thinke I were best to let
Thee alone indeed: but come, follow mee,
The Wild-cat shall not carry it so away,
Walke, walke, as we did.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: What, haue you fetcht your Champion? what can he do?
Not haue you, nor himselfe from out the storme
Of my incensed rage; I will thunder into your eares,
The wrongs that you haue done an innocent Mayde:
Oh you're a cupple of sweet: What shall I call you?
Men you are not; for if you were,
You would not offer this vnto a Mayde.
sp.p: Wherein haue I deserued it at your handes? Haue I not been, alwayes a kind Sister to you; & in signes & tokens shewed it? Did I not send Money to you at Cambridge when you were but a Freshman, wrought you Purses and Bandes; and since you came toth' Inns a Court, a faire payre of Hangers? Haue you not taken Rings from mee, which I haue been faine to say I haue lost, when you had paund them: and yet was neuer beholding to you for a payre of Gloues?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: A Womans tongue I see, is like a Bell,
That once being set a going, goes it selfe.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: And yet you to ioyne with my sister against mee,
Send one heere to play vpon mee, whilst you laugh and leere,
And make a pastime on mee: is this Brotherly done?
sp.p: No it is Barberous, & a Turke would blush to offer it to a Christian: but I will thinke on't, and haue it written in my heart, when it hath slipt your memories.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: When will your tongue be wearie?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: How neuer? Come talke, and Ile talke with you,
Ile try the nimble footmanship of your tongue;
And if you can out-talke mee, yours be the victorie.

div.stage: Heere they two talke and rayle what they lift; then Rash speakes to Stayns.

sp.speaker: All speake.
sp.l: Vds'foot, dost thou stand by, and doe nothing?
Come talke, and drowne her clamors.

div.stage: Heere they all three talke, and Ioyce giues ouer weeping, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Alas, shees spent yfayth: now the stormes ouer.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Vds'foot, Ile follow her as long as I haue any breath.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Nay no more now Brother, you haue no compassion,
You see shee cryes.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: If I do not wonder she could talke so long, I am a villaine,
She eats no Nuts I warrant her: sfoot, I am almost out of breath
With that little I talkt: well Gent. Brothers I might say;
For shee and I must clap hands vpon't: a match for all this.
Pray goe in; and Sister, salue the matter, collogue with her
Againe, and all shall be well: I haue a little businesse
That must be thought vpon, and tis partlie for your mirth;
Therefore let mee not (tho absent) be forgotten:
Fare well.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: We will be mindfull of you sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How now man, what tyerd, tyerd?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Zounds, and you had talkt as much as I did, you would be tyrd I warrant: What, is shee gone in? Ile to her againe whilst my tongue is warme: and if I thought I should be vsde to this exercise I woulst eate euery morning an ounce of Lickorish. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lodge the maister of the Prison, and Lock-fast his man.

sp.speaker: Lodge.
sp.p: Haue you sumd vp those Reckonings?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lodg.
sp.p: And what is owing mee?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Thirtie-seuen pound odd monie,

sp.speaker: Lodg.
sp.p: How much owes the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: A fourtnights Commons.

sp.speaker: Lodg.
sp.p: Has Spendall anie monie?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Not any sir: and he has sold all his Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Lodg.
sp.l: That fellow would wast Millions, if he had them;
Whilst he has Monie, no man spends a pennie:
Aske him monie, and if he say he has none,
Be plaine with him, and turne him out o'th Ward. Exit Lodg.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.l: I will sir. Maister Spendall,
My Maister has sent to you for monie.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Monie, why does he send to mee? does he thinke
I haue the Philosophers Stones, or I can clip or coyne?
How does he thinke I can come by monie?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Fayth sir, his occasions are so great, that hee must haue monie, or else he can buy no Victuals.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Then we must starue, belike: Vdsfoot thou seest
I haue nothing left, that will yeeld mee two shillings.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.l: If you haue no monie,
You're best remoue into some cheaper Ward.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What Ward should I remoue in?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Why to the Two-pennie Ward, is likliest to hold out with your meanes: or if you will, you may goe into the Holl, and there you may feed for nothing.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: I, out of the Almes-basket, where Charitie appeares
In likenesse of a peece of stinking Fish:
Such as they beat Bawdes with when they are Carted.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.l: Why sir, doe not scorne it, as good men as your selfe,
Haue been glad to eate Scraps out of the Almsbasket.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: And yet slaue, thou in pride wilt stop thy nose,
Scrue and make faces, talke contemptibly of it, and of the feeders; surely groome.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.l: Well sir, your mallapertnes will get you nothing.
Fox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Heere.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: A prisoner to the Holl, take charge of him, and vse him as scuruily as thou canste you shall be taught your duetie sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Hence slauish tyrants, instruments of torture,
There is more kindnesse yet in Whores, then you,
For when a man hath spent all, hee may goe
And seeke his way, theyle kicke him out of dores;
Not keepe him in as you doe, and inforce him
To be the subiect of their crueltie.
You haue no mercie; but be this your comfort,
The punishment and torturs which you doe
Inflict on men, the Diuels shall on you.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.l: Well sir, you may talke, but you shall see the end,
And who shall haue the worst of it. Exit Lock.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Why villaine, I shall haue the worst, I know it,
And am prepard to suffer like a Stoicke,
Or else (to speake more properly) like a Stocke;
For I haue no sence left: dost thou thinke I haue?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Zounds, I thinke hee's madde?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Why, thou art i'th right; for I am madde indeed,
And haue been madde this two yeare. Dost thou thinke
I could haue spent so much as I haue done
In wares and credite, had I not been madde?
Why thou must know, I had a faire estate,
Which through my ryot, I haue torne in peeces,
And scattered amongst Bawdes, Buffoons, and Whores,
That fawnd on mee, and by their flatteries,
Rockt all my vnderstanding faculties
Into a pleasant slumber; where I dreampt
Of nought but ioy and pleasure: neuer felt
How I was luld in sensualitie,
Vntill at last, Affliction waked mee:
And lighting vp the Taper of my soule,
Led mee vnto my selfe; where I might see
A minde and body rent with Miserie.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Harry Fox, Harry Eox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Who calles?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Heer's the Bread and Meate-man come.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Well, the Bread and Meate-man may stay a little.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Yes indeed Harry, the Bread and Meat-man, may stay:
But you know our stomacks cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Indeed your Stomacke is alwayes first vp.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.p: And therefore by right, should be fire serued: I have a stomacke like Aqua fortis, it will eate any thing:
sp.l: O Father Gatherscrap, here are excellent bits in the Basket.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Will you hold your Chops further; by and by youle driuell into the Basket?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Perhaps it may doe some good; for there may be a peece of powderd Beefe that wants watering.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Heere sir, heer's your share.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Heer's a bit indeed: whats this to a Gargantua stomack?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Thou art euer grumbling.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Zounds, it would make a Dogge grumble, to want his Victuals: I pray giue Spendall none, hee came into'th Holl but yester-night.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: What, doe you refuse it?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I cannot eate, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: No, no, giue it mee; hee's not yet seasond for our companie.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Deuide it then amongst you. Exit Fox & Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: To such a one as these are, must I come,
Hunger will draw mee into their fellowship,
To fight and scramble for vnsauerie Scraps,
That come from vnknowne hands, perhaps vnwasht:
And would that were the worst; for I haue noted,
That nought goes to the Prisoners, but such food
As either by the weather has been tainted,
Or Children, nay sometimes full paunched Dogges,
Haue overlickt, as if men had determind
That the worst Sustenance, which is Gods Creatures,
How euer they're abusde, are good enough
For such vild Creatures as abuse themselues.
O what a Slaue was I vnto my Pleasures?
How drownd in Sinne, and ouerwhelmd in Lust?
That I could write my repentance to the world,
And force th'impression of it in the hearts
Of you, and my acquaintance, I might teach them
By my example, to looke home to Thrift,
And not to range abroad to seeke out Ruine:
Experience shewes, his Purse shall soone grow light,
Whom Dice wastes in the day, Drabs in the night:
Let all auoyde false Strumpets, Dice, and Drinke;
For hee that leaps in Mudde, shall quickly sinke.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Yonder's the man.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I thanke you.
How is it with you, sir? What on the ground?
Looke vp, there's comfort towards you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Belike some charitable Friend has sent a Shilling,
What is your Businesse?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Libertie.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: There's vertue in that word; Ile rise vp to you.
Pray let mee heare that chearefull word againe.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The able, and wel-minded Widdow Raysby,
Whose hand is still vpon the poore mans Box,
Hath in her Charitie remembred you:
And beeing by your Maister seconded,
Hath taken order with your Creditors
For day, and payment; and freely from her Purse,
By mee her Deputie, shee hath dischargd
All Duties in the House: Besides, to your necessities,
This is bequeathd, to furnish you with Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Speake you this seriously?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Tis not my practise to mocke Miserie.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Be euer praysed that Deuinitie,
That has to my oppressed state raysd Friends:
still be his blessings powred vpon their heads:
Your hand, I pray,
That haue so faythfully performd their willes:
If ere my industrie, ioynd with their loues,
Shall rayse mee to a competent estate,
Your name shall euer be to mee a friend.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: In your good wishes, you requite mee amply.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: All Fees, you say, are payd? there's for your loue.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I thanke you sir, and glad you are releast. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How Apparell makes a man respected; the very children in the streete do adore mee: for if a Boy that is throwing at his lacke-alent chaunce to hit mee on the shinnes: Why I say nothing but, Tu quoque, smile, and forgiue the Child with a becke of my hand, or some such like token: so by that meanes, I do seldome goe without broken shinnes.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: The blessings of your Mistres fall vpon you,
And may the heat and spirit of Hee-lip,
Endue her with matter aboue her vnderstanding,
That she may only liue to admire you, or as the Italian sayes;
Que que dell fogo Ginni Coxcombie.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I doe wonder what language he speakes.
Doe you heare my friend, are not you a Coniurer?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: I am sir, a perfect Traueller, that haue trampled ouer
The face of this vneuerss. and can speake Greeke and
Latine as promptly, as my owne naturall Language:
I haue composd a Booke, wherein I haue set downe
All the Wonders of the world that I haue seene,
And the whole scope of my Iornies, togeather with the
Miseries and lowsie fortunes I haue endured therein.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: O Lord Sir, are you the man; giue me your hand:
How doe yee: in good fayth I thinke I haue heard of you.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: No sir, you neuer heard of mee, I set this day footing
Vpon the Wharffe, I came in with the last peale of Ordinance,
And dind this day in the Exchange amongst the Marchants.
But this is friuelous and from the matter: you doe seeme
To be one of our Genteell spirrits that doe affect Genorositie:
Pleaseth you to be instituted in the nature, Garb. and habit,
Of the most exactest Nation in the world, the Italian:
Whose Language is sweetest, Cloaths nearest, and hauiour
Most accomplisht: I am one that haue spent much monie,
And time; which to me is more deare then monie, in the
Obseruation of these things: and now I am come,
I will sit me downe and rest, and make no doubt,
But by qualitie, to purchase and build, by professing this Art,
Or humane Science (as I may tearme it,) to such Honorable
And Worshipfull personages as meane to be peculiar.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: This fellow has his tongue at his fingers endes:
But harke you sir, is your Italian the finest Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: In the world Signeor, your Spaniard is a meere Bumbard to him: hee will bounce indeed; but hee will burst: But your Italian is smooth and loftie, and his language is, Cozen germane to the Latine.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why then hee has his Tu quoque in his salute?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Yes sir, for it is an Italian word as well as a Latine,
And infoldes a double sence: for one way spoken,
It includes a fine Gentleman like your selfe;
And another way, it imports an Asse, like whom you will.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I would my man Iaruis were heere, for hee vnderstands these thinges better then I. You will not serue?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Serue, no sir, I haue talkt with the great Sophy.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I pray sir, whats the lowest price of being Italianated?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Sir, if it please you, I will stand to your bounty:
And marke me, I will set your face like a Grand signeors,
And you shall march a whole day, vntill you come opounctly to your Mistirs,
And not disrancke one hayre of your phisnomie.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I would you would doe it Sir, if you will stand to my
Bounty, I will pay you, as I am an Italian tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Then sir, I will first disburthen you of your Cloake,
You will be the nimbler to practise: Now sir, obserue mee,
Goe you directly to the Lady to whom you deuote your selfe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: You shall set a good stay'd face vpon the matter then.
Your Band is not to your Shirt, is it?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No sir, tis loose.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: It is the fitter for my purpose.

I will first remooue your Hatte, it has been the fashion (as I haue heard) in England, to weare your Hatte thus in your eyes; But it is grosse, naught, inconuenient, and proclaymes with a loude voyce; that hee that brought it vp first, stood in feare of Sargiants. Your Italian is contrarie, hee doth aduance his Hatte, and sets it thus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Excellent well: I would you would set on my head so.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Soft, I will first remoue your Band, and set it out of the reach of your eye; it must lie altogeather backward: So, your Band is well.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is it as you would haue it!

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: It is as I would wish; onely sir, this I must condition you off; in your affront or salute, neuer to mooue your Hatte: But heere, heere is your curtesie.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay I warrant you, let mee alone; if I perceiue a thing once, Ile carrie it away: Now pray sir, reach my Cloake.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Neuer whilst you liue, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No, what doe your Italians weare no Cloakes?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Your Signeors neuer: you see I am vnfurnisht my selfe.

div.stage: Enter Sir Lyo Will Rash, Geraldine, Widdow, Gartred, and Ioyce.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Sa'y so' prethee keepe it then. See, yonder's the companie that I looke for; therefore if you will set my face of any fashion, pray doe it quickly?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
You carry your face as well as eare an Italian in the world, onely inrich it with a Smyle, and tis incomparable: and thus much more, at your first appearance, you shall perhaps
strike your acquaintance into an extasie, or perhaps a laughter: but tis ignorance in them, which will soone be ouercome, if you perseuer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will perseuer, I warrant thee; onely doe thou stand aloofe and be not seene, because I would haue them thinke I fetcht it out of my owne practise.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Do not you feare, Ile not be seene, I warrant you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Now Widdow, you are welcome to my house,
And to your owne house too; so you may call it:
For what is mine, is yours: you may command heere,
As at home, and be as soone obayde.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: May I deserue this kindnesse of you, sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Saue you Gent. I salute you after the Italian fashion.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: How, the Italian fashion? Zounds, he has drest him rarely

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: My sonne Bubble, I take it?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: The nether part of him I thinke is hee,
But what the vpper part is, I know not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: By my troth hee's a rare fellow, he sayd true:
They are all in an extasie.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I thinke hee's madde?

sp.speaker: Ioy
sp.p: Nay that can not bee; for they say, they that are madde, loose their wits: and I am sure he had none to loose.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: How now sonne Bubble, how come you thus attyrde
What, do you meane to make your selfe a laughing stocke, ha?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Vm; Ignorance, ignorance.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: For the loue of laughter, looke yonder,
Another Hearing in the same pickle.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: The tother Hobby-horse I perceiue is not forgotten.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Who has made him such a Coxcombe troe?
An Italian tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: I salute you according to the Italian fashion.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Puh, the Italian fashion? the tatterd-de-malian fashion hee meanes.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Saue you sweete bloods, saue you.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Why but what ligge is this?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Nay if I know father, would I were hangd,
I am e'ne as Innocent as the Child new borne.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: I but sonne Bubble, where did you two buy your Felts?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Felts? By this light, mine is a good Beauer:
It cost mee three pound this morning vpon trust.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Nay, I thinke you had it vpon trust: for no man that has any shame in him, would take mony for it: behold Sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Nay neuer doe you laugh, for you're i'th same blocke.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is this the Italian fashion?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: No, it is the Fooles fashion:
And we two are the first that follow it.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Et tu quoque, are we both cozend:
Then lets shew our selues brothers in aduersitie, and imbrace.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: What was hee that cheated you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Marry sir, he was a Knaue that cheated mee.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: And I thinke he was no honest man, that cheated mee,

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Doe you know him againe, if you see him?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Yes I know him againe, if I see him:
But I doe not know how I should come to see him.
O Iaruis, Iaruis, doe you see vs two, Iaruis?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Yes sir, very well.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: No, you doe not see vs very well;
For we haue been horribly abused:
Neuer were Englishmen so guld in Italian, as we haue been.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Why sir, you haue not lost your Cloake and Hatte.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Iaruis you lie, I haue lost my Cloake and Hatte:
And therefore you must vse your credite for another.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: I thinke my old Cloake and Hatte, must be glad to serue mee till next quarter day.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Come, take no care for Cloakes, Ile furnish you;
To night you lodge with mee, to morrow morne
Before the Sunne be vp, prepare for Church,
The Widdow and I haue so concluded on't:
The Wenches vnderstand not yet so much,
Nor shall not, vntill bedtime: then will they,
Not sleepe a wincke all night, for very ioy.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: And Ile promise the next night,
They shall not sleepe for ioy neither.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: O Maister Geraldine, I saw you not before:
Your Father now is come to towne, I heare?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Were not my businesse earnest, I would see him:
But pray intreat him breake an howers sleepe
To morrow morne, t'accompanie mee to Church;
And come your selfe I pray along with him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: But looke, heere comes one,
That has but lately shooke off his Shackles.
How now sirra, wherefore come you?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: I come to craue a pardon sir, of you,
And with heartie and zelous thankes
Vnto this worthy Lady, that hath giuen mee
More then I ere could hope for: Libertie.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Be thankfull vnto Heauen, and your Maister:
Nor let your heart grow bigger then your Purse,
But liue within a limit, least you burst out
To Ryot, and to Miserie againe:
For then t'would loose the benefite I mean it.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: O you doe graciously, tis good aduice:
Let it take roote firra, let it take roote.
But come Widdow come, and see your Chamber;
Nay your companie too, for I must speake with you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Tis bound vnto you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: And I haue to talke with you too, Mistris Ioyce:
Pray a word.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: What would you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray let me see your hand: the line of your Maydenhead is out. Now for your Finger; vpon which Finger will you weare your wedding Ring?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Vpon no Finger.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Then I perceiue you meane to weare it on your thumb.
Well, the time is come sweet Ioyce, the time is come.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: What to doe, sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: For mee to tickle thy Tuquoque; to doe the act of our forefathers: therefore prepare, provide,
To morrow morne to meete mee as my Brde. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Ile meete thee like a Ghost first.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: How now, what matter haue you fisht out of that foole?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Matter as poysning as Corruption,
That will without some Antidote strike home
Like blew Infection to the very heart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: As how, for Gods sake?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: To morrow is the appoynted Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: The day of doome it is?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: T'would be a dismall day indeed to some of vs.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Sir, I doe know you loue mee; and the time
Will not be dallyed with: bee what you seeme,
Or not the same: I am your Wife, your Mistris,
Or your Seruant; indeed what you will make mee:
Let vs no longer wrangle with our Wittes,
Or dally with our Fortunes; lead mee hence,
And carry mee into a Wildernesse:
Ile fast with you, rather then feast with him.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: What can be welcommer vnto these armes?
Not my estate recouerd, is more sweete,
Nor strikes more ioy in mee, then does your loue.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Will you both kisse then vpon the bargaine,
Heer's two couple on you; God giue you ioy,
I wish well to you, and I see tis all the good that I can doe you:
And so to your shiftes I leaue you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Nay Brother, you will not leaue vs thus, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why what would you haue me do, you meane to run away togeather, would you ha me run with you, and so loose my Inheritance: no, trudge, trudge with your backes to mee, and your bellies to them: away.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Nay I prethee be not thus vnseasonable:
Without thee wee are nothing.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: By my troth, and I thinke so too: you loue one another in the way of Matrimonie, doe you not?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What else man?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: What else man? why tis a question to be askt;
For I can assure you, there is an other kind of loue:
But come follow mee, I must be your good Angell still:
Tis in this braine how to preuent my Father, and his brace
Of Beagles: you shall none of you be bid to night:
Follow but my direction, if I bring you not,
To haue and to hold, for better for worse, let me be held an
Eunuch in wit, and one that was neuer Father to a good Feast.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: Wee'le be instructed by you.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Well, if you bee, it will be your owne another day.
Come follow mee.

div.stage: Spendall meetes them, and they looke strangely vpon him, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: How ruthlesse men are to aduersitie,
My acquaintance scarce will know mee, when wee meet
They cannot stay to talke, they must be gone;
And shake mee by the hand as if I burnt them:
A man must trust vnto himselfe, I see;
For if hee once but halt in his estate,
Friendship will prooue but broken Crutches to him:
Well, I will leane to none of them, but stand
Free of my selfe: and if I had a spirit
Daring to act what I am prompted too,
I must thrust out into the world againe,
Full blossomd with a sweete and golden Spring:
It was an argument of loue in her
To fetch mee out of Prison, and this night,
She claspt my hand in hers, as who should say,
Thou art my Purchase, and I hold thee thus:
The worst is but repulse, if I attempt it:
I am resolud, my Geneus whispers to mee
Goe on and win her, thou art young and actiue;
Which she is apt to catch at, for there's nought
That's more vnsteadfast, then a womans thought.

div.stage: Enter Sir Lyo, Will Rash, Scatter-good, Bubble, Widdow, Gartred, Ioyce, Phillis, and Seruant.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Heere's ill lodging Widdow: but you must know,
If wee had better, wee could affoord it you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: The lodging Sir, might serue better Guestes.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Not better, Widdow, nor yet welcommer:
But wee will leaue you to it; and the rest.
Phillis, pray let your Mistris want not any thing,
Once more Good night, Ile leaue a kisse with you,
As earnest of a better Guift to morrow.
Sirrah, a Light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Good rest to all.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Et tu quoque, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: God giue you good-night, forsooth,
And send you an early resurrection.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: God-might to both.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: Come, come away, each Bird vnto his nest,
To morrow night's a time of little rest. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Heere vntie: soft, let it alone,
I haue no diposition to sleepe yet:
Giue mee a Booke, and leaue mee for a while,
Some halfe houre hence, looke into mee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I shall forsooth. Exit Phillis.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: How now, what makes this bold intrusion?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Pardon mee Lady, I haue busines to you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Busines, from whom, is it of such importance
That it craues present hearing?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: It does.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Then speake it, and be briefe.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Nay gentle Widdow, be more plyant to mee.
My suite is soft and courtious: full of loue.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Of loue?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Of loue.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Why sure the man is madde? bethinke thy selfe,
Thou hast forgot thy errand?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: I haue indeed, faire Lady; for my errand
Should first haue been deliuered on your lippes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Why thou impudent fellow, vnthrift of shame,
As well as of thy purse; What has mooud thee
To prosecute thy ruine? hath my bountie,
For which thy Maister was an orator,
Importune thee to pay mee with abuse?
Sirra retire, or I will to your shame,
With clamors rayse the house, and make your Maister
For this attempt, returne you to the Dungion,
From whence you came.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Nay then I must be desperate:
Widdow, hold your Clapdish, fasten your Tongue
Vnto your Roofe, and do not dare to call,
But giue mee audience, with feare and silence:
Come kisse mee: No?
This Dagger has a poynt, doe you see it?
And be vnto my suite obedient,
Or you shall feele it too:
For I will rather totter, hang in cleane Linnen,
Then liue to scrub it out in lowsie Lynings.
Goe too, kisse: You will? why so: Againe: the third time?
Good, tis a sufficient Charme: Now heare mee,
You are rich in Mony, Lands, and Lordships,
Mannors, and fayre Possessions, and I haue not so much
As one poore Coppy-hold to thrust my head in.
Why should you not then haue compassion
vpon a reasonable handsome fellow,
That has both youth and liuelihood vpon him;
And can at midnight quicken and refresh
Pleasures decayed in you? You want Children,
And I am strong, lusty, and haue a backe
Like Hercules, able to get them
Without the helpe of Muscadine and Eggs:
And will you then, that haue inough,
Take to your Bed a bundle of diseases,
Wrapt vp in threescore yeares, to lie a hawking,
Spitting, and coffing backwards and forwards
That you shall not sleepe; but thrusting forth
Your face out of the Bed, be glad to draw
The Curtaines, such a steame shall reeke
Out of this dunghill. Now what say you?
Shall we without further wrangling clap it vp,
And goe to Bed togeather?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Will you heare mee? Knocke within.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Yes with all my heart,
So the first word may bee, Vntrusse your Poynts.
Zounds one knocks: do not stirre I charge you,
Nor speake, but what I bid you:
For by these Lippes, which now in loue I kisse,
If you but struggle, or but rayse your voyce,
My arme shall rise with it, and strike you dead.
Go too, come on with mee, and aske who's there?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It is my Mayde.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: No matter, doe as I bid you: say, Who's there?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Who's there?
Within Phillis .Tis I, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: If it be you, forsooth, then pray stay.
Till I shall call vpon you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: If it be you forsooth, then pray you stay,
Till shall call vpon you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Very well, why now I see
Thou'lt prooue an obedient wise, come, let's vndresse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Will you put vp your naked weapon sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: You shall pardon mee (Widdow) I must haue you grant first.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You will not put it vp.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Not till I haue some token of your loue.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: If this may be a testimonie take it. Kisse him.
By all my hopes I loue thee, thou are worthy
Of the best widdow liuing, thou tak'st the course;
And those that will win widdowes must doe thus.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Nay, I knew what I did, when I came with my naked weapon in my hand; but come, vnlace.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Nay my deare loue, know that I will not yeeld
My body vnto lust, vntill the Priest
Shall ioyne us in Hymens sacred nuptiall rites.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Then set your hand to this, nay 'tis a contract
Strong and sufficient, and will holde in Lawe,
Heere, heere's pen and incke, you see I come prouided.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Giue me the penne.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Why here's some comfort,
Yet write your name faire I pray,
And at large; why now 'tis very well,
Now widdow you may admit your Maid,
For i'th next roome I'le goe fetch a nappe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Thou shalt not leaue me so, come pre thee sit,
Wee'l talke a while, for thou hast made my heart
Dance in my bosome I receiue such ioy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Thou art a good wench yfaith, come kisse vpon't.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: But will you be a louing husband to me,
Auoyde all naughty company, and be true
To me, and to my bedde?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: As true to thee, as Steele to Adamant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I'le binde you to your word, see that you be,
Or I'le conceale my bagges, I haue kins folkes,
To whom I'le mak't ouer, you shall not haue a penny.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Push, pre thee doe not doubt me,
How now, what meanes this?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It means my vengeance; nay sir, you are fast,
Nor doe not dare to struggle, I haue libertie,
Both of my tongue and feet, I'le call my maid:
Phillis come in, and helpe to triumph, Enter Phillis.
Ouer this bolde Intruder, wonder not wench,
But goe vnto him, and ransacke all his pockets,
And take from thence a Contract which he forc'd
From my vnwilling fingers:

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Is this according to your oath.

sp.speaker: Phillis
sp.l: Come sir, I must search you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: I pre thee do.
And when thou tak'st that from me, take my life too.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Hast thou it gerle?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I haue a paper heere.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It is the same, giue it me, looke you sir,
Thus your new fancied hopes I teare asunder:
Poore wretched man, t'hast had a golden dreame,
Which guilded o're thy calamitie:
But being awake thou findst it ill laid on,
For with one finger I haue wip'd it off:
Goe fetch me hither the Casket that containes
My choicest Iewells, and spread them heere before him;
Looke you sit:
Heere's gold, pearle, rubies, saphires, diamonds;
These would be goodly things for you to pawne,
Or reuell with amongst your Curtizans,
Whilst I and mine did starue: why dost not curse,
And vtter all the mischiefes of thy heart,
Which I know swells within thee, powre it out,
And let me heare thy fury.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Neuer, neuer:
When ere my tongue shall speake but well of thee,
It prooues no faithfull seruant to my heart.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: False traitor to thy maister, and to me,
Thou liest, there's no such thing within thee.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: May I be burn'd to vglinesse, to that
Which you and all men hate, but I speake truth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: May I be turn'd a monster, and the shame
Of all my Sex,— and if I not beleeue thee,
Take me vnto thee, these, and all that's mine,
Were it thrice trebled, thou wert worthy all:
And doe not blame this triall, cause it shews
I giue my selfe vnto thee, am not forc'd,
And with't alone, that ne'r shall be diuorc'd.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: I am glad 'tis come to this yet, by this light
Thou putt'st me into a horrible feare:
But this is my excuse: know that my thoughts
Were not so desperate as my actions seem'd,
For fore my dagger should ha drawne one droppe
Of thy chaste blood, it should haue sluc'd out mine:
And the cold point strucke deepe into my heart:
Nor better be my fate, if I shall moue
To any other pleasure but thy loue.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It shall be in my Creed: but lett's away,
For night with her blacke Steeds drawes vp the day. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Rash, Staines, Geraldine, Gartred, Ioyce, and a Boy with a Lanthorne.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Softly Boy, softly, you thinke you are vpon firme ground, but it is dangerous; you'l neuer make a good thiefe, you rogue, till you learne to creepe vpon all foure: if I do not sweare with going this pace: euery thing I see, mee thinkes, should be my father in his white beard.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: It is the property of that passion, for feare
Still shapes all things we see to that we feare.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Well said Logicke, sister, I pray lay hold of him, For the man I see is able to giue the Watch an answere, if they Enter Spendall, Widdow, and Phillis .should come vpon him with Interrogatories: zownds wee are discouered, boy, come vp close, and vse the property of your Lanthorne: what dumbe shew should this be?

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.l: They take their way directly, intend nothing gainst vs.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Can you not discerne who they are?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.l: One is Spendall.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: The other is the Widdow as I take it.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: T'is true, and that's her maid before her.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: What a night of conspiracie is heere, more villanie? there's another goodly mutton going, my father is fleeced of all, griefe will giue him a box yfaith, but 'tis no great matter, I shall inherit the sooner, nay soft sir, you shall not passe so currant with the matter, I'le shake you alittle: who goes there?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Out with the Candle, who's that askes the question?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: One that has some reason for't.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: It should be, by the voyce, yong Rash.
Why we are honest folkes.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Pray where do you dwell? not in towne I hope.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: Why we dwell, zownds where doe we dwell?
I know not where.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: And you'l be married you know not when, zownds it were a Christian deed to stoppe thee in thy iourny: hast thou no more spirit in thee, but to let thy tongue betray thee. Suppose I had beene a Constable, you had beene in a fine taking, had you not!

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: But my still worthy friend,
Is there no worse face of ill bent towards me,
Then that thou merrily putt'st on.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Yes, heere's foure or fiue faces more, but ne'r an ill one, though neuer an excellent good one, Boy, vp wish your lanthorne of light, and shew him his associats, all running away with the flesh as thou art, goe yoake together, you may be oxen one day, and draw all together in a plough, go march
together, the Parson staies for you, pay him royally, come, giue me the Lanthorne, for you haue light sufficient, for night has put off his blacke Cappe, and salutes the morne, now farewell my little children of Cupid, that walke by two and two as if you went a feasting: let mee heare no more words, but be gone.

sp.speaker: Spend. & Sta.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Gart. & Ioyce
sp.p: Farewell brother. Manet Rash.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: I, you may crie farewell, but if my father should know of my villanie, how should I fare then? but all's one, I ha done my sisters good, my friends good, and my selfe good, and a generall good is alwaies to be respected before a particular, ther's eight score pounds a yeare saued, by the conueyance of this widdow, I heare footesteps, now darkenesse take me into thy armes, and deliuer me from discouery. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.p: Lord, lord, what a carelesse world is this, neyther Bride nor Bridegroome ready, time to goe to Church, and not a man vnroosted, this age has not seene a yoong Gallant rise with a candle, we liue drowned in feather-beds, and dreame of no other felicitie: this was not the life when I was a yong man, what makes vs so weake as wee are now? a feather-bed: what so vnapt for exercise? a feather-bed: what breedes such paines and aches in our bones? why a feather-bed or a wench, or at least a wench in a feather-bed: is it not a shame, that an olde man as I am should be vp first, and in a wedding day, I thinke in my conscience there's more mettall in laddes of three score, then in boyes of one and twenty. Enter Basket hilt .Why Basket hilt.

sp.speaker: Bask.
sp.p: Heere sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Shall I not be trussed to day?

sp.speaker: Bask.
sp.p: Yes sir, but I went for water.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Is Will Rash vp yet?

sp.speaker: Basket.
sp.p: I thinke not sir, for I heard no body stirring in the house.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Knocke sirra at his chamber, Knocke within.
The house might be plucked downe and builded againe
Before hee'd wake with the noyse. Rash aloft.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Who's that keepes such a knocking, are you madde?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Rather thou art drunke, thou lazy slowch,
That mak'st thy bed thy graue, and in it buriest
All thy youth and vigor; vp for shame.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Why 'tis not two a clocke yet.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Out sluggish knaue 'tis neerer vnto fiue,
The whole house has out-slept themselues, as if they had drunk wilde poppy: Sirra, goe you and raise the maides, and let them call vpon their mistresses.

sp.speaker: Bask.
sp.p: Well sir, I shall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Did I eate any Lettice to supper last night, that I am so sleepie, I thinke it be day light, brother Bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What sai'st thou brother? heigh ho!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Fie, fie, not ready yet? what sluggishnesse
Hath seiz'd vpon you? why thine eyes are close still.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: As fast as a Kentish oyster, surely I was begotten in a Plumb-tree,
I ha such a deale of gumme about mine eies. Enter Seruant.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Lord how you stand! I am asham'd to see
The Sunne should be a witnesse of your slouth,
Now sir, your haste.

sp.speaker: Bask.
sp.p: Marry sir, there are guests comming to accompany you to church.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: Why this is excellent, men whom it not concerns
Are more respectiue then we that are maine Actors.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Father Rash, be not so outrageous, we will goe in and buckle our selues, all in good time, how now! what's this about my shinnes? Enter old Geraldine, and Long-field.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Me thought our shankes were not fellowes, we haue metamorphosed our stockings for want of splendor. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray what's that Splendor?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Why 'tis the Latin word for a Christmasse candle

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l:
O Gentlemen, you loue, you honour mee, welcome,
welcome good Master Geraldine, you haue taken paines
To accompany an vndeseruing friend. Enter Phillis.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: You put vs to a needelesse labour sir,
To runne and winde about for circumstance,
When the plaine word, I thanke you, would haue seru'd.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: How now wench, are the females ready yet?
The time comes on vpon vs, and we runne backeward:
We are so vntoward in our busines,
We thinke not what we haue to doe, nor what we doe.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I know not sir whether they know what to doe, but I am sure they haue beene at Church well-nie an houre, they were afraid you had got the start of them, which made them make such haste.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: I'st possible, what thinke you Gentlemen?
Are not these wenches forward? is there not vertue in a man can make yong Virgins leaue their beddes so soone.
But is the widdow gone along with them?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Yes sir; why she was the ring-leader.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: I thought as much, for she knowes what belong's to't,
Come Gentlemen, me thinkes 'tis sport to see
Yong wenches run to church before their husbands: En. Rash.
Faith we shall make them blush for this ere night:
A sirra, are you come? why that's well said;
I marl'd indeede that all things were so quiet,
Which made me thinke th'ad not vnwrapt their sheets:
And then were they at Church I holde my life:
Maides thinke it long vntil ech be made a wife.
sp.stage: Enter Spend Sta. Geraldine, Widdow, Gartred, and Ioyce.
sp.l: Hast thou my cloake knaue? well said, put it on,
Wee'l after them; let me goe hasten both,
Both the Bridegroomes forward, wee'l walke a little
Softly on afore: but see, see, if they be not come
To fetch vs now, we come. we come,
Bid them returne, and saue themselues this labour.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Now haue I a quartane ague vpon me.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p: Why how now! why come you from Church to kneele thus publikely, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: We kneele sir for your blessing.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How, my blessing! Master Geraldine, is not that your sonne?

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: Yes sir, and that I take it is your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: I suspect knauery, what are you?
Why doe you kneele hand in hand with her?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: For a fatherly blessing too sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Hoy day! 'tis palpable, I am gull'd, and my sonne
Scatter-good and Bubble fool'd, you are married?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes sir, we are married.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: More villanie! euery thing goes the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: We shall goe the right way anone, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Yes marry shall you, you shall eene to the Counter againe, and that's the right way for you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: O you are wrong,
The prison that shall hold him are these armes.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I doe feare that I shall turne stinckard, I do smell such a matter: you are married then?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Ecee signum, heere's the wedding Ring t'affirme it.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: I beleeue the knaue has druncke Ipocras,
He is so pleasant.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: God morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Tu quoque to all: what, shall we goe to Church?
Come, I long to be about this geare.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Doe you heare me, will you two goe sleepe againe? take out the tother nap, for you are both made Cockescombes, and so am I.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: How, Cockes-combes!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Yea Cockes-combes.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Father, that word Cockes-comb goes against my stomacke.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And against mine, a man might ha digested a Woodcocke better.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: You two come now to goe to church to be married,
And they two come from Church, and are married.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How, married! I would see that man durst marry her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why sir, what would you doe?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why sir I would forbid the banes.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: And so would I.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Doe you know that youth in Sattin, hee's the penner that belongs to that Inck-horne.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How, let me see, are not you my man Geruase?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes sir. Enter a Sergeant.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And haue you married her?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And doe you thinke you haue vsde me well?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: O intollerable rascall! I will presently be made a Iustice of Peace, and haue thee whipp'd, goe fetch a Constable.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Come, y'are a flourishing Asse; Sergeant take him to thee, he has had a long time of his pageantry.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Sirra let him goe, I'le be his baile, for all debts which come against him.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Reuerend sir, to whom I owe the duty of a sonne,
Which I shall euer pay in my obedience:
Know that which made him gracious in your eyes,
And guilded ouer his imperfections,
Is wasted and consumed euen like ice,
Which by the vehemence of heate dissolues,
And glides to many riuers, so his wealth,
That felt a prodigall hand, hote in expence,
Melted within his gripe, and from his coffers,
Ranne like a violent streame to other mens,
What was my owne, I catch'd at.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Haue you your morgage in?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Stand vp, the matter is well amended,
Master Geraldine, you giue sufferance to this match.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Yes marry doe I sir, for since they loue,
I'le not haue the crime lie on my head,
To diuide man and wife.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Why you say well, my blessing fall vpon you,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And vpon vs that loue sir Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: By my troth since thou hast tane the yong knaue,
God giue thee ioy of him, and may he proue
A wiser man then his Master.

sp.speaker: Sta
sp.l: Sergeant, why dost not carry him to prison?

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: Sir Lyonell Rash will baile him.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: I baile him knaue! wherefore should I baile him?
No, carry him away, I'le relieue no prodigalls.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Good sir Lyonell, I beseech you sir, Gentlemen, I pray make a purse for me.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: Come sir, come, are you begging?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why that does you no harme Geruase, master I should say; some compassion.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Sergeants, come backe with him, looke sir, heere is your liuery,
If you can put off all your former pride,
And put on this with that humilitie
That you first wore it, I will pay your debts,
Free you of all incombrances,
And take you againe into my seruice.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tenter-hooke let mee goe, I will take his worships offer without wages, rather then come into your clutches againe; a man in a blew coate may haue some colour for his knauery, in the Counter he can haue none.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: But now M. Scatter-good, what say you to this?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Marry I say 'tis scarce honest dealing for any man to Conny-catch another mans wife, I protest wee'l not put it vp.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: No, which we?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Why Gartred and I.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Gartred, why shee'l put it vp.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Will she?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I that she will, and so must you.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Must I?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes that you must.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.l: Well, if I must, I must: but I protest I would not:
But that I must: So vale, vale: Et tu quoque. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: Why that's well said,
Then I perceiue we shall wind vp all wrong:
Come Gentlemen, and all our other guests:
Let our well-temper'd bloods taste Bacchus feasts,
But let vs know first how these sports delight,
And to these Gentlemen each bid good night.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.l: Gentles, I hope, that well my labor ends,
All that I did was but to please my friends.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A kind enamouret I did striue so proue,
But now I leaue that, and pursue your loue.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.l: My part I haue performed with the rest,
And though I haue not, yet I would doe best.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: That I haue cheated through the Play, 'tis true,
But yet I hope, I haue not cheated you.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.l: If with my clamors I haue done you wrong,
Euer hereafter I will hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.l: If through my riot I haue offensiue beene,
Henceforth Ile play the ciuil Citizen.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Faith all that I say, is, how ere it happe,
Widdowes like Maids sometimes may catch a clappe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: To mirth and laughter henceforth I'le prouoke ye,
If you but please to like of Greenes Tu quoque.
